Two inches of water and several long strands of hair were found in the ice bucket and mold growth was evident in the grout of the shower. Neither were deeply disgusting but things that should never happen at a resort with the Waldorf Astoria label. Otherwise the room was very nice and newly renovated. The bed was quite comfortable and the bathroom very spacious. The lanai was the most enjoyable aspect of the room as it provided wonderful views and comfortable chairs. Food: My God! Terrible Terrible Terrible. I fully expected the prices that were charged at the restaurants in the resort but the quality of the food was just shamefull at any price. Utter disappointment to each of the three restaurants. Beach and Pools: Couldn't be better. Five star beach and pools. Various Charges: Everything at the Grand Wailea has a price. Nickel and dimed is the feeling one gets. I'll never understand the logic of a $25.00 resort charge on top of the room rate. In the end this is a very nice resort but certainly not remotely the same caliber of the Four Seasons right next door. This hotel is probably just too large to be a five star hotel and the staff although pleasant and helpful if pressed, are not what they should be.

Reviews.Title: “Great for teens, would be TERRIBLE if full”
Reviews.Author: Mel1Sydney
Reviews.Content: I feel it helps to know who is writing a review, so others can judge if they are looking for the same things: we are in our late 40s, like luxury, good food, clean facilities and top service. If we are paying a top price, we expect the best. We spent 7 nights (April 13-20) at the GW with 2 thirteen yr old girls, staying in adjoining Napua Tower Club rooms (We had to pay $25 per night to guarantee connecting rooms. They tried to charge us PER ROOM for this, ie $50 per night, but took it off when I complained). The girls had 2 queen beds, we had a king. These rooms are very large, well equipped, clean, with fabulous bathrooms (see my pics). We could see the ocean only from our balcony, which really didn't bother us that much as we are from Sydney and surrounded by ocean but it may matter if you are coming from somewhere else. The service in the Club areas was very good. (We noticed that guests in other rooms had to carry their own luggage, for example) Breakfast was included in the Club lounge - it finishes at 10.30am which was about 1/2 hr too early, I thought (teenagers like to sleep in!). Also they start clearing away at 10.20, which was annoying. It is not a full breakfast, but we found plenty there - fresh fruit, a wide selection of cereals, breads, one hot dish, pastries, juices. We also made use of the Club lounge every evening for cocktails and canapes (on from 5-6.30pm). Great spicy bloody marys and my DH loved his vodka martinis! Hot snacks (chicken skewers or spring rolls) were not good, but fresh veggies and dips were just fine. We made use of the excellent gym - large with the latest equipment, plenty of towels and water. The spa was superb (except the rooms were too bright for my liking) - very clean hydro baths and spa pools, really worth having at least one treatment there (we had two each, including one duo massage). The therapists were good, which is not often the case in hotel spas. The food was either average or very bad (in the Japanese restaurant). The only decent meal we had on Maui was at Spagos at the 4 Seasons next door. Huma Huma, the GW signature restaurant, was fine - nothing terrible but not really notable either. The bistro was a bistro - sandwiches, french fries, lousy burgers. I don't understand why Americans put strange orange cheese on everything, but that's another discussion! Our teenagers had a FANTASTIC time and we were SO THANKFUL for the adult pool. When one man had his 3 year old in there, we complained right away - it took a while for staff to get him out (what was worse, HE was staff on a day off!), but we kept complaining and finally he got out. The kids pool areas, with slides and rope swings, a "river" and hot tub is really great - for kids! Our girls loved it and were old enough to hang out there on their own - and that is the ONLY way I could survive this place. Having to be around the family pool area would have been awful for us. We were also extremely lucky, it seems..... For the first 5 days I would guesstimate that the hotel was about 1/2 full - plenty of green lawn, chairs by the ocean and adult pool, no waiting for restaurants and the gym was empty. Then, on the day before we left, a convention arrived. It was appalling and the whole character of the place changed immediately. Suddenly the elevators took much longer to arrive, we had to wait longer for our food to be served, it was harder to find pool chairs... on and on, you get the picture. This was sheer luck (though I would never go to a resort like this during high seasons like spring break, Xmas, Easter etc) and we are most thankful. Also, I really resent the $25 per day per room "resort" fee - what is THAT about? I knew about it, but I still don't get it. And yes, you have to pay for shade - umbrellas or cabanas. That's just another blatent rip-off. Bottom line? A great place if it's not too full and wonderful for teens. (I do not understand why honeymooners would choose a resort this size. Problem with 4 Seasons, however, is that there is no adult pool - go to Tahiti or one of the smaller isles!) Hope this, and the pics, help (it would really be helpful, I feel, if people would only post pics of rooms and bathrooms. Views not really help me decide on a hotel, unless of course the view is so awful it needs warning about!!) We had a great holiday cause the kids had so much fun and we got lucky with the crowds.

Reviews.Title: “Awesome”
Reviews.Author: menten101
Reviews.Content: This place was so amazing. It was royal paradise. Everything was first class, even the beach! I HIGHLY recommend it. We went during labor day week and it was still fabulous. we didn't take our kids buts I saw parents with kids and they didn't seem out of place. I will definitely go again, probably with the kids next time- Toi Menten

Reviews.Title: “Terrible customer service”
Reviews.Author: caracciolo04
Reviews.Content: This hotel claims to be 5 star and its the worst experience we have ever had at a resort of this rating. It started with the hotel not getting us into our room until 6:30PM when we arrived at the hotel at 2PM. They told us to sit in the lobby and our room would be ready in 30 minutes. We were told every 30 minutes from then to wait. We have 4 kids and they were bored to death. When we finally got our room we opened our laptop bag to find out it the screen was cracked and we had just used it in the car on the way to the hotel. So we waited on security to file its report and was told the insurance would take care of it. NOT! Since we have came home we received a letter that said they were not responsible for it. This was a brand new apple laptop and we know the bellman did it. They just acted like they would take care of it to get us off the island. Totally professional!! The grounds of the resort were full of trash. They did not clean the pool grounds the entire time we were there. We were at the pool everyday. The room had ants in it and they were very small. I will never stay at this resort again and its a shame. Last of all the food is way over priced and is comparable to some cheap fast food place. My advice is to stay somewhere else and don't fall for the 5 star rating when its not.

Reviews.Title: “Heaven on Earth - There is nothing not to love!”
Reviews.Author: totie44
Reviews.Content: I knew the Grand Wailea would be nice - but it exceeded my expectations. Everything from check in to the kids camp - day and evening, to the pools, to the rooms. to the grounds and the food was excellent. The grounds are absolutely wonderful - both inside and out. Our friends children loved the day and evening kids camp - so much so they attended nearly every day. The pool is amazing, has great bar service and really nice food. The slides, the staff and the pool are really above the best. This really great review goes for both the adult and family pool. We ate at all of the restarants and enjoyed all of them. The Sunday brunch was very very good. They were all really good - as were most of the placed in the Wailea mall - which is a short walk away. Tje beach area is perfect - with chairs and tools as necessary. I very much enjoyed that area. The rooms were a very nice size and the bathrooms were upscale. Do not hesitate to stay at the Grand Wailea! I cannot imagine you not liking it!

Reviews.Title: “Management should do a better job.”
Reviews.Author: eekthetripsinaweek
Reviews.Content: This resort has gone downhill (hotel room wise, that is), ever since new management took it over several years ago. The Front Desk staff was just doing their job, and took no effort to make you feel welcome or at home. Their adult pool was littered with screaming kids, all of which seemed to have been dumped there by their parents, never to return again. Their two saving graces is their spa, that was spectacular according to my wife (believe me, she has been to each and every single one of them in Maui), and their grounds are always perfectly manicured. With all the great vacation rentals around, they're really giving places like this a run for their money. Please do a better job, Grand Wailea, or you'll be yesterday's news in no time.

Reviews.Title: “Fair stay at the Grand Wailea”
Reviews.Author: SemoJim
Reviews.Content: We recently stayed at the Grand Wailea for spring break with our 3 kids. Overall, the service was quite good, but the resort certainly lacks the excellence that the price would indicate you should get. In general most staff members were very good, but for the price they are competing with the Four Seasons and Ritz Carlton's of the world, and Hilton just doesn't live up to those standards. Even though the prices are the same. The pool and beach are terrific and if you are bringing your kids of any age, they will love it. There is nonstop fun and activities which is why we booked the hotel. Getting a chair poolside is difficult but the hotel was sold out while we were there. Food is expensive and average at best. Dinner at Humuhumu was not good at all, but very expensive. That restaurant is clearly a problem for the resort. Rooms are reportedly being renovated and they need it. Our rooms were clean but are in need of updating. Check in and check out was a pleasant surprise. Very wlll done. Overall the resort was what we wanted in terms of entertaining our family. We loved the activities, pool and beach. It's truly a wonderful resort, but, for the price, we would definitely go next door to the Four Seasons if we weren't with our kids.

Reviews.Title: “Awful, Awful, Awful”
Reviews.Author: ExpatinTokyo
Reviews.Content: After looking forward to a week of sheer luxury, the Grand Wailea was a massive disappointment. Things did not get off to a good start when we arrived tired and jet lagged at 12 noon off a flight from Japan and asked whether we could check in earlier than the normal 3pm time. The front desk said that they would contact housekeeping to get our room ready early and took our mobile phone number, so they could tell us when the room was ready. Two hours passed with no contact, so we went back to the front desk. They assured us that the room was being given the express treatment. Three o'clock came and went, and at around 3:15pm we were taken by a bell hop to a filthy room which hadn't been touched. The bell hop rang down to the front, who said that they had given us the wrong room. Eventually, we were placed in the right room and the bell hop fled from embarrassment without explaining any of the room's facilities and without hanging around for a tip (the one and only time at our stay in the resort). My sense from was that housekeeping had no intention of getting a room ready before 3pm and we were just fobbed off by the front desk. After unpacking, we headed down to the pool. The place was packed. Not a free chair in sight. When we turned up poolside the next day around 10am, the same situation. This is where I part company with all those four and five star reviews for this same hotel I have read. In a true luxury hotel, you do not have to fight for a pool side seat, you do not have to rush down to the pool at the crack of dawn to place your towel on a seat, you do not have to pay $100 a day to reserve a bit of shade. This is not what a luxury hotel does. This is what a mass market, mid-level or worse hotel does. Indeed, the hotel seemed intent on gouging clients at every turn. From internet access, to umbrellas on the beach, to the daily resort charge (what is this? surely when you book a room at the price of this hotel, you assume that you will be using the resort facilities). Finally, the food was truly terrible value for money. We tried the Bistro Molokini, Grand Dining Room, Cafe Kula and the Japanese restaurant Kincha. In every case you got second rate food for around two to four times the price you would pay in a good city restaurant. Everything appeared to be out a tin, instant mix or the freezer. Given everything has to be shipped into Maui, I can see the limitations. But true luxury hotels that have island locations around the world like the Four Seasons work around this - that is why you pay big bucks: so as to get good, well cooked fresh food. At the Grand Wailea you pay big bucks to get tarted-up school canteen slop. Finally, I got caught up in the airline bankrupcty problems during my stay and had to switch my flight out to Hawaiin Airlines from Aloha. Stupidly, I thought that I could use the Grand Wailea's clout to help navigate my way through all the ticketing chaos rather than waste a whole day on the phone and internet. Of course, they were not interested in helping (even up to the Day Manager level). Again the contrast with a real luxury hotel is telling: in such hotels, the senior people at the front desk have a degree of autonomy and flexiblity in problem solving for clients. At the Grand Wailea, if it is not in their rule book, they are not interested. In conclusion, for all those people who have rated this hotel highly (and for the senior management of the Grand Wailea who don't appear to get it), all I can say is try a true luxury hotel. It costs the same you know. The experience you will have at the Mandarin, Peninsula, Four Seasons and Shangri-la is at a completely different level. Amazingly, the Waldorf Astoria has lent its brand to the Grand Wailea. I don't know what they are thinking. This is a classic way to damage a luxury brand. It fooled me into booking this hotel once, but not again! And now I will also think twice about booking any Waldorf Astoria worldwide.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointed”
Reviews.Author: TravelOpportunist
Reviews.Content: For us, the key to happiness at the Grand Wailea is low expectations. Unfortunately, we checked in here after 5 lovely nights at the newly remodeled Ritz Carlton where we were pampered the entire time. Driving up we waited for 10 minutes at the valet. We then decided to just self park rather than continue to wait. We found the only open spot available in self parking and then made our way to check-in. We got in line behind 20 or so other people and just 2 check-in clerks. We noticed 6 bellmen just standing there. Why don't they cross-train the bell-people to be able to check people in when there is a lengthy delay? When we finally made it to the front of the line, the clerk immediately up-sold us to a "garden view" for an extra $100/night on top of the $550 we paid for the mountain view rooms which she claims look at the parking lot. Stupidly, we accepted. My brother checked in later and was automatically given a garden view just down the hall from us. It appears they are remodeling the mountain view rooms as they have stacked the beds outside on the lanai (lovely) so I suspect everyone gets upgraded automatically except those stupid enough to fall for the up-sale. The rooms are definitely in need of an upgrade. At the Ritz we had an empty fridge we could use and were regularly given free bottled water. At the GW, if you are stupid enough to drink the water they leave for you, you will be charged $6 bucks each. No free newspaper here. You have to go to the Cafe and buy one yourself. The bathroom toiletries were the worst, generic quality I have experienced in years. They even use "creme rinse" instead of conditioner. I didn't even think they made creme rinse anymore. At the end of the 3 days, my hair was like a brillo pad. Our room looked over the Activity pool. We were awoken at 6:30 am by people who started to stake their claim to the precious pool chairs. We quickly dressed and waited in line at the towel desk. Chairs are crammed together and you are sure to become friends with you neighbor, as your chair will be touching theirs. By 7:10am, there were essentially no chairs available unless you wanted to sit on the beach or on the grass. Cabana's are $300 and require up to a one-year advance reservation. The pool itself was fun for the 1st day but the amount of debris floating in the water made me queasy. Used Band-aids, trash, leaves, you name it, you are swimming in it. Given the Four Seasons next door is roughly the same price, we would never stay here again. I suppose if you have children and do not stay anywhere else before hand (so you have nothing to compare it to) this hotel would be satisfactory. For us, we couldn't wait to leave after the 3 nights we spent at the GW.

Reviews.Title: “A Grand Time!”
Reviews.Author: PrettyKitties
Reviews.Content: Welcoming: My teenaged daughter and I stayed for a week at the Grand in a deluxe ocean view room. The trip was her high school graduation present and I had hoped that it would be very special. It was! From the moment we pulled up in our rental car, we felt pampered and fussed over. The bell captain was very helpful in explaining the check in process. We were given leis after we got out of the car and even my daughterâ€™s stuffed leopard received a lei! Check in was effortless and the bellboy was extremely helpful. He also took time to tell us everything we needed to know about our room and the hotel. Room: The room was clean and well appointed. The very best part was the lanai - at night I kept the door open so I could sleep while being soothed by the warm ocean breezes and sounds. Ahhhh! The view from the lanai was drop dead gorgeous â€“ we were even able to see whales! The lanais have a table and a couple of chairs. The beds were extremely comfortable. There is turn-down service every night, although frankly I found it annoying that they closed the lanai doors. After a couple of days, I requested that they stop the turn-down service, which was no problem. Housekeeping is impeccable. Throughout the stay, I was not bothered by noises from the other rooms. Bathroom: The bathroom was very large and spacious. There is a separate shower with a seat, which we really liked. The water pressure in the shower was not the best, but it was adequate. The tropical smelling shampoo and conditioners were great! Linens were generously sized and very luxurious. Room amenities: Real glassware is provided in the room, along with a coffee maker, tea and coffee. Mini refrigerators are available at $25 for your stay. In my opinion, the refrigerators are well worth the cost. Before we arrived at the room, we stopped at K-Mart and stocked up on sodas, wine, drinks, etc - definitely a money saver. (By the way, the bottled water by the coffee maker costs over $6 a pop.) There is a mini-bar, but we kept it locked. A safe, ironing board and iron are provided in the room. The room does have free high speed internet wireless and hooking up was easy. On the welcome screen, there are two options, one free and a fee-based upgrade for higher bandwidth. The free option was sufficient for our needs (mostly just surfing and checking e-mail) and the speed seemed comparable to my DSL service at home. Meals: I was somewhat disappointed by the Bistro Molokini â€“ the food is above average but it is overpriced and service was only fair. We got most of our resort meals from the CafÃ© Kula - which had decent offerings. It was still expensive, but less pricy than the resortâ€™s full service restaurants. (The Belgian waffles are terrific!) The cafÃ© does have an outdoor eating area with ocean views but for evening meals, we preferred to take our food upstairs to eat on the lanai. If you are willing to walk over to the Shops at Wailea (about a leisurely ten minute walk), the Whaler General Store has a deli which is much more affordable if you just want something light. If you are staying at the Grand, you must try the Grotto bar â€“ which is actually in the pool under a waterfall! You are supposed to be 21 and over to sit at the bar, but the bartender was kind enough to let my daughter sit at the bar for a bit when it wasnâ€™t busy. Can life get any better than to be under a waterfall drinking a frou-frou drink while sitting IN the pool?! Grounds: The grounds are beautiful and well kept. As you pull in the main drive, there is a gorgeous waterfall on the right. There are pools throughout the resort with lots of koi and even some turtles. The pool by the Humuhumu has a lot of colorful tropical fish. Artwork and flowers abound throughout the property. Pool/beach: Of course, the Grand has a great pool with lots of fun stuff, but we spent most of our time on the beach. The beach is very clean as is the ocean floor â€“ you will not need sandals in the water. Even wading out a bit, you can still see the ocean floor. There are plenty of beach chairs (you have to pay for the blue and white cabana chairs). Because this is the leeward side of the island, the waves are generally mild â€“ not the place for surfing. Boogie boards, kayaks, etc are available for rent in a shore-side kiosk and can be charged to your room. My daughter did rent a boogie board ($20 for 24 hours) and was able to ride a few waves. (If you want to boogie board a lot, I would suggest buying one on the island rather than renting on a daily basis. We saw some for about $20 at Hilo Hatties.) There is a shower for cleaning your feet by the beach. Even though it was spring break, I did not find the beach to be overly crowded. Miscellaneous stuff: The resort does have valet parking for $20 a day or free parking. The free parking spaces are small and all seem to be next to a concrete pillar. Maneuvering in and out of the spaces is difficult. There are no laundry facilities for the guests and the resort charges for laundry by the piece. The business center has computers with internet access for a fee. However, printing boarding passes is free. (When we left from OGG, there was a LONG line for people checking in without boarding passes and no line for those with boarding passes. So, it is definitely worth while to print your boarding passes before leaving the resort.) We only stopped by the concierge once (the desk is well staffed) and he was very helpful. Overall, resort staff was friendly and ready with a smile. If you plan to stay on the grounds after checking out (noon), we were told that there is a courtesy room to keep your stuff until you leave and that you can still use the resort facilities. The check out process is simple and a mistake on my bill was promptly handled. Should you spend all of your time at the resort?: You could very easily â€“ but the answer is no! Maui has a lot to offer and if you are staying a week, there is simply not enough time. Activities we enjoyed included kayaking, snorkeling, seeing the sunrise on Haleakala, hiking, horseback riding (Piâ€™iholo and Lahaina ranches), a whale watching boat ride (awesome!), spending time in Lahaina and Paâ€™ia and visiting Hoâ€™okipa Beach to watch the surfers. My biggest problem was scheduling enough time to enjoy the resort!

Reviews.Title: “No Class, No Chairs at the Grand Wailea”
Reviews.Author: sophiemclean
Reviews.Content: Our party of six stayed our last two nights in Hawaii at the Grand Wailea, which was advertised as a first class resort, part of the Waldorf Astoria Collection of the Hilton Hotel chain. Sadly, the reality is that the hotel has a low-class, concession stand feel about it, where after spending $3000 for two rooms for two nights, we were nickeled and dimed at every turn. Every person at the pool is required to wear a wristband, even the adults; If your child wants an inner tube, you have to purchase one - as a result, hundreds of unused and abandoned inner tubes litter the property. If you need a snorkel mask, no problem, for $30 a day they will rent you one. (Snorkel Bob's rented us a brand new prescription mask for $10 a day). If you expect to sit, you better be willing to pay. Cabanas are $250; Casabellas $150 and teak lawn chairs $75, according to the extension you were directed to call in the hotel information booklet. This is in additon to the $25.00 per day per room resort fee. The first day we arrived early (10 a.m.), but not early enough and could find no chairs anywhere by the pool area to lay down our items, much less sit. The next day we arose early, had breakfast and went to sit in the pool area. There we found restrictive signs all over the place asking you to pay for cabanas, casabellas, etc. but then we found a little grassy area between the pool and the beach where chairs were scattered haphazardly and no signs. My husband arranged some chairs in order and we sat down. Three hours later, we were told by hotel staff that we would have to pay $150 for the chairs, or move down to the beach. Since our 12 year old daughter was in the pool, and since there had been no sign telling us we could not sit in this area, we refused to move, but were embarrassed and offended at the suggestion that we had done something wrong, when in fact we had made every effort to find a spot not restricted by signs (there are a lot of signs prohibiting you from sitting down!!). I complained to the front desk and sometime later was approached again by the same employee who, by way of obstensible apology, said that we could stay there today, but would have to pay tomorrow. Again, embarrassed in front of our children by the suggestion that we had done something wrong, I informed the employee not to worry, that we were checking out the next day, never to return. I then requested a meeting with management, and was met by the Assistant Director of Food and Beverage for the Pool, who claimed to be the highest ranking management on site at the hotel. (It was a Sunday). In response to my inquiry whether, after spending $3000 for two days it was reasonable for me to expect at least one chair for our party of six, the manager said, no, It was unreasonable: that the hotel couldn't possibly provide chairs for all the guests who wanted them; that, in fact, the hotel did not want to charge for chairs, but was "forced to" in order to accomodate the wishes and demands of those guests who "really wanted" chairs.The next day, an operating manager called my husband, a Hilton Gold VIP member, and told him that the reason there were no signs where we sat down was because he had already spent $10,000 this year in signage and there was no more money in the budget for signs. I respectifully suggest that the money would have been better spent finding a place for his guests to sit. Ultimately, we were given a $200 credit upon checkout for our complaint (too little too late), and I was upset enough to cancel our dinner reservation at the fine dining restaurant (on the theory that I was not spending one more dime at the hotel, much less $600+ for our party of six). But, in the end, It is clear that whoever classified the Grand Wailea as part of the Waldorf Astoria collection has never stayed at either hotel. I have stayed at the Waldorf many times and was treated there with the respect I expected, but did not receive at the Grand Wailea. I am not sure what part of the experience is supposed to be first class, except for the fees you are charged. My suggestion is that you stay at the Mauna Lani on the Big Island, where you are treated from the moment you arrive as a first class guest at a first class resort. Chairs, internet, newspapers and pool use are free; guests are offered free popsicles and smoothie samples daily; towels are graciously provided without having to provide paperwork; no resort fee, various activities are offered daily for free. After your first afternoon, all of the staff miraculously remembers you by name. You are actually able to spend your time relaxing instead of figuring out what you are to pay for next.

Reviews.Title: “Expensive, but beautiful”
Reviews.Author: hrhsoleil
Reviews.Content: We stayed here three days before moving up the coast. The hotel is beautiful. Our bathroom literally made us gasp. Soaker tub, large shower. It was HUGE. The room was large, the bed was luxious and the lanai was private. This was the perfect place for us to decompress and wind down from the long trip. I don't think I would like staying here for an entire vacation (too isolated) but it was the perfect place to begin our vacation. There's a long paved beach walk and the pools are great fun. The food and drinks are at the resort are expensive ($18 for a hamburger). Refridgerators are extra, so we ended up buying a cooler at the local grocery for fruit, beer, soda and wine. For a great dinner, I recommend Sensei Restaurant in nearby Kihei. It's a local favorite. Don't be fooled by the plain storefront -- the food is absolutely amazing!

Reviews.Title: “See and be seen at the Grand Wailea”
Reviews.Author: Michelle2013
Reviews.Content: This is definitely a 5 star property, but it is also not for everyone. The grounds are beautifully landscaped, there is a gorgeous view to the ocean, and the hotel is filled with artwork and fountains. The spa is one of the best in the world. The pools are fantastic for kids with the slides, and lazy river, and sand bottomed pool options. The beach is great with alot of good activities - easy to kayak or sail right off of it. Boogie boards to rent, and a water trampoline. The adult pool is very pretty too. So why not for everyone? First, it is body to body crowded. Although there are signs everywhere saying not to hold chairs, every morning between 7 and 8 there are streams of people headed to the pool taking up any available empty seat. If you are not there by 9, you need to walk around a crowded pool searching for an impossible to find single chair. We were there at a busy week and all the cabana tents had been reserved long before we even checked-in. There was no shade to be found or purchased. Second, this place nickel and dimes you. We got connecting rooms with our kids and had to pay an extra $25 PER room for the right to have the rooms connecting (total $50 extra a day). An extra $30 for the rollaway. $50/day for shade chairs at the beach or $300 for a cabana that was not available. ETC. It is not a hotel that offers excellent service. You find you own chairs by the pool, you wait in line at check in, you wait in line for towels, you trip a waitress for service. But, we had a great time at the fab beach and pool and spa, so I still recommend it. Just know that this is not where to go for a quiet, tasteful vacation. If you want real class, stay at the four seasons next door.

Reviews.Title: “Certainly GRAND!”
Reviews.Author: LJChick
Reviews.Content: We enjoyed our 3 nights as much as possible. All three kids came down with the flu so we did not do as much as we liked. The pools are fantastic. They also have a sandy beach pool that is shallow and our 3 year old loved it. We enjoyed the amazing views of the whales each day. The rooms are a bit cramped but we did spend more time in it due to the illness. We spent our next 3 nights at the Kia Lani and the rooms are much larger. Service by the pool was lacking. One of our favorite meals was at the Humma Humma Restaurant that sits on stilts over a pond filled with sealife. The kids thought that was cool.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Resort but...”
Reviews.Author: Viajerosin
Reviews.Content: We were very excited to visit this beautiful resort. It is huge and has tons of activities for everyone. The beach is awesome and swimmers friendly. What caught our attention was the service. The staff service was average and seemed to need more motivation to assist guests. One example: My husband's wallet was stolen the day prior to our departure. We went to concierge and explained the lady that we reported the stolen wallet several hours ago and we would like to check if somebody had returned it. She sent us to a guest phone to call Security. She did not even offer to make the call. In a resort like this one, at least you expect this offer as a courtesy. Besides that, the wallet was stolen in their premises. Customer service usually makes a huge difference and it is one of the main reasons to go back to a place. Certainly this would not be the case. Also, restaurants are very overpriced.

Reviews.Title: “Grand Wailea is Heaven for Kids and Adults”
Reviews.Author: Monolivdad
Reviews.Content: Just stayed here in March 2008, and yes it is true that if you plan on going to Maui, bring your wallet , but the Grand Wailea was worth every penny. Truly first class. I have two kids ages 8 and 11 and this is by far the best pool we have ever been too. Mutliple water slides, waterfalls, lazy river, water elevator ( a bit overrated but cool), a tarzan rope into the pool, enough to keep you busy. Kids could not stay awake past 8pm after a day in the pool. The staff at the resort were first class all the way, and although lunch by the pool with the kids will cost you a $ 100, all of their restaurants ( even the top one's ) had kids menus. There is always cold water or juice in the lobby and at the pools so you do not always have to keep buying $12 frozen drinks. The rooms were very big and the views spectactular. The Wailea are is a great part of the island, shops are close by for groceries and typical shopping etc.... Beach was great as well. One of the top spots for Snorkeling in Maui is right on the Grand Wailea Beach

Reviews.Title: “The Best!!!”
Reviews.Author: Dallas_TexasMomtotwo
Reviews.Content: We stayed here as part of a sales reward trip, and could not have been more pleased. The website photo's do not do it justice. The grounds and pools are fabulous. Our room was beautiful and very roomy. Yes, it is expensive but everything is Maui is. There is so much to do at the hotel, you never have to leave. We will definately go again.

Reviews.Title: “loved it!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!”
Reviews.Author: Wisconsin8
Reviews.Content: We loved Grand Wailea and all of Maui!! My husband and I are not kids people and we were not bothered at all by the "family feel". It was romantic and beautiful. We lucked out to go this time of year and see whales breaching right from our chairs on the beach. We never ate at the resort. Too expensive. There is plenty of choices for less inexpensive meals just down from the hotel. I really do not see what people complain about. Your in paradise in a BEAUTIFUL resort. Enjoy.

Reviews.Title: “Five Stars”
Reviews.Author: Seattle12
Reviews.Content: We have stayed at the Grand 5 times over the last 10 years. It is always breathtaking. The lobby, the gardens, the art and the pools are fantastic. The reason we keep coming back is because the kids love the pools and water features. In addition there is great snorkling less than 100 yards from the hotel. Snorkling with an 8 year old, we saw sea turtles, manta rays and even whales breaching in front of the hotel. Yes the Grand is expensive ("Grand Wallet" some say) you are paying for the experience. We prefer rooms overlooking the gardens and close to the beach. The grounds are big, and you can waste a lot of time walking. An ocean view is not needed, because hopefully you won't spend much time in the room. This area of Maui is almost always dry. We have been there in January and February and never had rain, and only a few clouds. Never a bad stay. If there is a downside, it is the convention trade. It is a big hotel and there are conventions. The feeling of the place changes with the conventions. One day it is mellow, and the next there are a bunch of conventioneers screaming into their cell phones by the pool.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hilton HHonors Experience”
Reviews.Author: oldogface
Reviews.Content: Well, having read about how the Grand Wailea needed renovations; about how everything costs so much and nickel and diming; having read about no HHonors privileges, and kids running rampant, I had set pretty low expectations about this trip. Fortunately, my experience was the opposite of all those negative reviews! We booked 6 nights for 300,000 HHonors points, and paid $500/night for two additional nights. I expected no upgrade, but we were upgraded to Napua Tower; I expected no HHonors "perks" but was immediately recognized as a Diamond member, given $25 certificate for use at Molokini Bistro, and 20% discount certificate for the spa - as well, as a welcoming letter from the manager (which said, by the way "If you're Diamond or Gold, and we haven't been able to give you a free upgrade, you will be given other options and additional HHonors points." I expected moldy carpets and furniture, peeling wallpaper, and dirty tile grout in the bathroom, but got a beautifully furnished, exceptionally maintained, spacious ocean-view room - my wife was especially happy that we could sit on the lanai and see Molokini, and watch whales. I expected to be charged extra for taking a deep breath, but, really found nothing out of line with any other top-line resort. Yeah, $18 for a burger is on the high side, but, look where you get to eat it! Maybe it was just the time of our visit, but, while we saw lots of kids, they certainly were neither pervasive, nor pests. We loved the idea that there was an adult pool - with lounges available as late as 9:30 in the morning (we were never unable to find a pair near the pool) and kids were over in there's doing whatever they wanted to do. Seems Hibiscus was heated, and activity pools were not, but they were certainly not uncomfortable - and at least as warm as the ocean! The staff was friendly and helpful, the facility was beautiful and comfortable. Loved the Hospitality Suite for shower and changing clothes on last day - we checked out of our room at 2:00 PM and stayed by the pool until 5:00 PM - and easily caught our 9:40 PM flight home. And, for those who think Wailea is too haughty, I believe you've got it wrong. Wailea is maintained and manicured, for sure, but the people and the facilities are as friendly and outgoing there as anywhere on the island. And, they tolerate rednecks like me!

Reviews.Title: “Wow! Way Better than Expectations”
Reviews.Author: dutchessofwinward
Reviews.Content: OK- I was very apprehensive about staying here given some of the reviews on this website. I am staying at the resort right now and can honestly say that this is one of the best (if not the best) Hilton resorts worldwide. I will give you that the prices are high. This is Maui, not Las Vegas-no $0.99 cent lobster buffets here. If you are expecting that, do not come here. Really. However, I can say that the hotel is maintained to the best standards. We moved from a garden view room to the Napuia Tower. The garden view was great. We actually had more room than in the "exculsive" tower. However, the walks to and from the pool were less in the tower, and this was better for my husband, who had just had hip replacement surgery. The service was first class and with a smile. We had dinner at the Four Seasons. "The Ultimate Romantic Dinner". Very expensive, but it was our 10th anniversary.. What we experienced was below standard for a Four Seasons. THIS IS IMPORTANT... While the view was incredible, patrons staying at the Four Seasons are stacked on top of each other. They simply do not have the room that the Grand Wailea does. So here I am, having this romantic dinner and had to listen to two male guests talk about the size of a (---). I stood up and made them aware of our presence, and they finally moved off, but it made more than a negative impression. Also, I had a meeting with the chef. While he did a great job, they forgot that I wanted a specific selection of wines and I paid an extra $150 for our wedding cake to be duplicated and IT WASN'T. They didn't duplicate it. I was really surprised and disappointed by that given that I had several conversations with the booking person and the pastry chef. So if you really must stay at the Four Seasons, Its really more about marketing than a better experience. (Think Lexus vs Toyota). The lobby and grounds are clearly nicer at the Grand Wailea. Its more about being a snob than about a better experience. Get yourself a bottle of spay Evian if you must, but stay at the Grand Wailea. You will have more room and a more grand experience. Oh-almost forgot-you get a better sunset view at HumaHuma vs Duo. Regarding maintenance, again, I can say it was first class. I have seen maintenance people routinely shining the brass. Unlike other reviews, when we had an issue with our room, if was fixed immediately. We encountered no weird smells and no issues that detracted from our stay. If you have an issue, I would speak up. I felt that they were attentive to any issue or concern that was valid. I have personally stayed at most Hilton resorts around the world. I would say this is by far the best. We went to the Maui Prince for a snorkel trip, and found that to be way below any standard. More like a Howard Johnson's. The Grand Wailea is really a First Class Resort. Its on one of the most beautiful beaches. And it is well maintained. You should not worry about coming here and staying. Honestly.

Reviews.Title: “Great property...but not for everyone”
Reviews.Author: Andriyko
Reviews.Content: My partner and I were really looking forward to going to Maui. All of our expectaions were exceeded both regarding the island and the hotel. Grand Wailea is a nice porperty with large rooms, huge territory, attentive staff and great location. Upon check-in we were upgraded to a Deluxe Seaview room as Hilton Diamond members. The staff is really attentive and pleasant so I am not sure why so many people complain. I guess it depends upon what people expect, and we are a rather demanding guests. The room's amenties are basic but the bathroom is huge (bigger than many rooms I have stayed in Europe). The adult pool is nice but really hard to get a place after 9am. The prices, of course, are ridiculous but nothing extraordinary compared to other resorts. The food is excellent so no disappointment there either. The only problem is this is a very family-oriented resort and we sometimes felt out of place. however, we had a great time and I would definetely come back!

Reviews.Title: “Positives far outweigh the negatives”
Reviews.Author: jenoro
Reviews.Content: Having read some of the earlier reviews, we were not sure what to expect. After our stay, we can easily say that our experience exceeded our expectations. Upon arriving, we were overwhelmed by the location and the beauty of the landscaping. The lobby is breathtaking and made us stop and stare. Having left a freezing Providence 12 hours earlier, this was quite a contrast. Our room was on the ground floor of the Lagoon wing, with a garden view. It was somewhat disappointing not to be able to see the ocean, but an ocean view was just a 100 foot walk away. We would describe the room as clean, but probably due for a makeover. The sofa in our room, as well as the armoire and TV were showing definite signs of wear and tear. We may have watched the TV for an hour our whole stay, so it wasn't a big deal at all. The bathroom was very clean and modern, no issues there. The king bed was really, really comfortable.....in my opinion, the most comfortable in the country!! There were a few fruitflies in the room, but in a hotel with no doors, and access to the beautiful outdoors with a large sliding door, what do people expect. Housekeeping should be commended, for keeping such a large property so clean and inviting. This was a real pleasant surprise based on some of the other reviews. We did not utilize the Spa, but we did utilize the Gym. It is a very nice workout facility versus what you get at other hotels. Lot of weight training equipment, as well as free weights, a real nice feature. As stated earlier, the prices here are WAY out of line.....but it is to be expected. We had rented a Jeep, and were able to go off property and found prices much more reasonable....however, we incurred the cost of a rental car for the week. Six of one a half dozen of the other. The self parking was very easy, and not that far away, and we weren't pressured or intimidated into using the valet service. There was not one rude or unwilling or unfriendly employee that we encountered. They were all friendly and more than willing to be of help or service. The pools and beach are beautiful. The adult pool was only populated by adults. The activity pool was busy, but not too overly crowded. It is funny however, to see nobody at the pool at 7am, but yet, so many chairs "reserved" with towels. There wasn't much of a problem finding chairs during the day though. The water elevator is interesting, for 1 ride, but overrated in our opinion. Overall, this is a great place to stay if you don't mind that feeling of staying in a large resort. You probably would not like it if you were looking for something a little more intimate. BTW, do not miss seeing the summit of Haleakala, or Oheo Gulch on the backside of the National Park. The natural beauty can not be duplicated anywhere else in the World. Also, for an evening out, Warren and Annabelle's Comedy Magic Show in Lahaina gets two huge thumbs up from us....and we're really not into that type of thing...but what a great show.

Reviews.Title: “LOVED the Spa!”
Reviews.Author: ceciliaboom
Reviews.Content: I was given a gift of a spa treatment at this beautiful hotel, and to be honest, I thought it was a bit pricey for a simple body scrub treatment. I quickly realized that it was worth every penny! Within the first moments I was made to feel very welcome, was given a robe and slippers, and offered a delicious herbal water as I entered the terme bath area. I never knew that taking a bath all morning long could be so relaxing and pleasant! There were different treatment baths, a waterfall bath, jet shower, champagne bubble bath, and conventional hot tubs, as well as cold plunge baths at my disposal. After a good two hours of unwinding and letting go of stress, I was called into a treatment room to undergo the body scrub, performed by a wonderful lady who was very friendly and professional - I enjoyed the Hawaiian sea salt, awapuhi ginger, and red alaea clay concoction so much that I even bought a bottle to take home. Afterwards, I steamed in a hot sauna and was able to shower off in the sauna as well. After another hour of bathing and rinsing, I spent some time on the lanai overlooking the glorious grounds of the Grand and taking in the breath-taking view of Wailea's waters. I finished the day with a hot bubble bath and a quick, invigorating, electrifying plunge into the freezing water of the cold plunge pool. I could not have had a more perfect day! I was completely renewed and energized and ready to start another day of rigourous hiking and swimming.

Reviews.Title: “Gorgeous and First Class in every respect”
Reviews.Author: FrequentBizTraveler
Reviews.Content: As a frequent traveller, I'm not one to gush over hotels, but this one is an exception. The property is first-class and gorgeous in every respect. Beautiful property and rooms, attentive and friendly staff, gorgeous grounds and beach. Yes, it's pricey. The only drawback is it is relatively secluded... other than the other resorts right next door, there is really nothing else around so you end up spending all of your time at the resort. If you are looking at an all-inclusive, relaxing place, you will be very happy here. This would be an outstanding honeymoon spot.

Reviews.Title: “great time, excellent facilities”
Reviews.Author: nysteve
Reviews.Content: After staying at the GWR for the last 10 days and having read some of the negative reviews, the experience has made me lose my faith in sites such as tripadvisor.com because the negative reviewers, who are likely as qualified to review a nice hotel as they are to practice nuclear physics, may unfortunately put some people off of staying at this great hotel, and that would be a shame. These small minded negative reviewers would likely find fault with heaven, if they get there. I travelled with the family and 3 older kids - 18, 14, 10 and this beautiful hotel is excellent in every way and was a great experience for all. Service - PERFECT. Every encounter with every staff member for 10 days was fine, from the initial meet and greet to the check out - the staff is happy, helpful and pleasant to be around. Rooms - We had 2 adjacent rooms and had absolutely no complaints - roomy, clean, great views. Pool area - pools are the best I have seen anywhere in the world for kids and if you go there with no kids there is a completely separate, large pool section for adults. Also the areas are very well maintained. It was very crowded but kept clean as reasonably possible. Service for drinks and food was fine each day considering the crowd. There was the early rush to get towels (which they had enough of), and the best seating, but no large family oriented hotel anywhere has solved that problem. Beach - nice and large, by Maui standards, lots of activities for all. Crowd - light on from the east coast so attitudes were few and far between, some major celebs, many many kids, overall pleasant. Restaurants - only had breakfast (good) at the hotel on some days since there are over 300 eating establishments in Maui to try and we like to get out. Spa - none better. General cost - this is an expensive establishment and that includes everything. Some prices are way over the top and if you go there expecting average to high prices you will be disappointed. High and very high is what you will get so bargain hunters beware. (You can mitigate some costs simply by shopping for drinks/snacks/booze at the local market.) If you have experienced large fine hotels in the past and if that type of establishment is your cup of tea, and if you are not on a budget and do not get offended by high prices then I would recommend you stay at the GWR if you go to Maui. You will not be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: “Great family vacation!”
Reviews.Author: Iluvtwins
Reviews.Content: Our extended family of 10 stayed at this resort after Christmas and through New Years. We had a great time. We loved the pools and enjoyed the spa. The hotel is very big and spread out. Unfortunately we were given rooms in the very back rear corner of the resort. It took us about 10 to 15 min. to get to the pool each day with the kids and their stuff. I would recommend getting a room in the Lagoon wing of the hotel. This is the closest to the pools. Our rooms were good size and were very clean. However, they did show some aging like peeling walllpaper, etc. The maids did a great job each day and turned down our rooms each night. The food was great by the pool. We really enjoyed the hamburgers. However, they were expensive at about $18. We had the breakfast buffet each morning because with 10 people it was difficult finding a table and ordering at Cafe Kula. If I was going to Maui again with kids, I would definately choose this hotel. If you are going without kids, I would stay at the Kei Lani down the way. The Four Seasons was way to "Hollywood" and the Marriott was not as nice for the price.

Reviews.Title: “Grand is Expensive and worth it”
Reviews.Author: davidcee
Reviews.Content: Just finished 9 day stay, our third stay in 7 months. I just find the deluxe ocean view and the large 640 sq ft. room to the most delicious vacation I have ever had. The fitness center and spa is rated one of the 10 best in the world, and you must check it out to understand how fabulous the Grand is. Expensive, YES! Worth it, yes. Our twice a day maid service kept everything clean and fresh, and after sleeping late most mornings, we hardly spent time in the room. The large adult pool (Habiscus) is extremely quiet, and we made new friends every day sitting in the jacussi or around the pool. With no kids in sight, everybody was more relaxed and friendly. The kids have their own water slide pool, and the beach is right at the edge of the pools. Most of the people I talked to had been to the Grand before, and were making plans for their next visit. Expensive and worth it.

Reviews.Title: “Great wedding place”
Reviews.Author: travelwanderer
Reviews.Content: We had a very nice wedding here. We only had a few guests so we decided to do the morning wedding. We arrived after the big storm that everyone was talking about so we were very lucky. The pictures turned out surprisingly great even though most people will say that sunset photos are better. It has to do with the light bouncing off that glow on your face. Nevertheless, I think our photographers did a wonderful job in capturing every moment. In terms of photo-ops this hotel has a lot to offer. We only stayed here for the wedding day and moved to a rental home afterwards. Few tips: Monday morning is lawn care day so that might ruin your wedding moment. There was a beach bash behind the chapel the day before the wedding and there were lawn chairs/tables/ stage setup going on. It made me worried and luckily on my wedding day the setup was gone. So be prepared unless you rent out that space yourself.

Reviews.Title: “Nice but, some age better than others”
Reviews.Author: Kawhona
Reviews.Content: We stayed in Wailea for 4 days as part of our week in Maui. While the resort is well located if you want to stay on that part of the island the hotel shows its age. It needs a bit of a Joan Rivers treatment to bring it back up to par. The check in process is much too unorganized for a resort of this caliber but, that is balanced a bit by the friendly and helpful staff. Good snorkling beaches are close by. Yes it is a bit overpriced for its current condition if you want top shelf the Ritz is probably the better choice but, it is serviceable.

Reviews.Title: “Hope you didn't book rooms here yet....”
Reviews.Author: COJOWisconsin
Reviews.Content: Let me start by saying the lobby of this resort is beautiful . I stayed here with my husband and two kids (12&10) in an ocean view with 2 double beds from 12/27-1/1/08. It was very roomy but we had a big ant problem. (We had stayed on the west side of the island at Kaanapali beach and had no bug problem for 7 days). We had them come spray our first night and again the next morning. When we got back from the pool all day the ants were back. We talked to the front desk when leaving for dinner and he offered another room to us. He stated 4 other ppl had complained about ants that day. He gave us 3 keys for the room so we would not have to stop back at the front desk. Once we inspected the new room he said we could just transfer our stuff to the new room and let the front desk know we were switching. We thought that was nice of him since the walk to the front desk from our room(s) was about 10 minutes. It took us an hour to pack up our stuff and move. We let the front desk know when we called for a bellhop. Our new room was outdated with old tile and decoration but was the same size. It was more noisy however since the staff rolled carts down the hall all night. Unfortunately we did not know this until we were trying to sleep! The next day we went on a snorkeling trip from 7-2:30. Upon returning to our room our key did not work. My husband had to trek back to the lobby where they said our rooms were never switched. My husband received a call from the manager soon after getting in the room . He waived our $25 resort fee for the two days we had problems and sent an amenities basket (very nice) 2 days later. I also surprised my husband with some birthday balloons and a cake delivered to our room on the 30th and it was great (FYI-$75 cost). The room service man was spectacular. Now on to the pool area. This was just awful. I will never stay at this resort again mainly for this fact. By 7:05 I would say all the chairs by the pool were reserved. They don't let you on the pool deck until 7! They have too many cabanas that rent out for $300 a day that have 4 chairs under the canopy plus it reserves the 4 chairs in front of it. Supposedly they have a worker that goes around and watches if no one comes to the reg. chairs after 1 1/2 hours he removes your items and the chairs open up for new ppl. Our first day I saw a zillion chairs never used until the afternoon and he never moved a thing! Another day we were going to brunch at a nearby hotel so we greased this pool worker $20 to keep our chairs just because we didn't want to lose them. There is a nice grassy area between the pool/walkway and beach with chairs that you have to RENT and RESERVE ahead of time. It was just ludicrus. We saw tons of ppl turned away because there were no chairs anywhere. Another day we had a reserved chair taken by another family who admitted to it upon our arrival . They offered it back but we declined since our kids were elsewhere at the time. Our 3rd chair we gave to a young couple with a 9 month old who I noticed had circled the pool 3x looking for 1 open chair. They have gone here for years and say the ppl just get ruder every year and we saw that this year as well! The walk to the pool was about 15 min. from our room. The layout of the property is just silly-you have to back track from your room to get the few elevators that take you down to the first level to head to the pool. They roll towel carts along the pool area all day long. You would think at an upscale hotel they would have a private walkway for that away from the ppl relaxing by the pool. It was obnoxious. The beach was back to back ppl and my kids could not even throw a nerf ball around-this was of course was not the hotels fault. The walkway north was nice but ppl are extremely rude (especially joggers) and won't even walk single file when passing others. Common sense is very lacking. I also did not like the Head Valet man because he was snooty and condescending to me when I asked about the shuttle service to shopping but EXTREMELY nice to a woman after me. The other valet ppl were very nice and quick . The concierge were nice too. Overall, the room size was the only good thing about the property besides the service but that was not exceptional. For dining, Longhis was scrumptious while I would really skip Cheeseburgers, Mai Tais and Rock and Roll in the Shops of Wailea. The service was horrible along with the burgers. We were told while shopping on a rainy News Years Eve that it always rains this day of the year so I would suggest leaving that day or 1/2 because 1/1 was absolutely gorgeous and it was tough to leave then! And when I go back, I won't stay here.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel! Already looking foward to going back!”
Reviews.Author: JayIs
Reviews.Content: Both my wife and I loved this place. First of all, its location is great. Walking onto the balcony and the ocean and Molokini is right in your sight. The famous Big Beach is only minutes drive away. The facility is very carefully maintained. We saw people polishing the door knobs and stair rails every day. The garden inside the hotel is just stunning. The hotel is also big, very big. It can be good or bad depending on peopleâ€™s taste. But we find it very interesting because there is a lot to explore. The room we had was a deluxe ocean view room. It is very clean and has all the amenities you can think of. We have nothing to complain about the staff. They are very helpful and very knowledgeable about what to do and where to go on Maui. The food in the resort is expensive. Thatâ€™s about the only drawback I can think of.

Reviews.Title: “Worst of Wailea”
Reviews.Author: Walter31
Reviews.Content: We were too late in booking to get a suite here for our Xmas 2007 trip (ended up in a condo) but went around to all hotels in Wailea and Kaanapali to scout for our next vacation. The Grand Wailea was our biggest disappointment! A colleague recommended it to us and their website makes it look truly "grand" but in person you could tell it was rundown as soon as you set foot on the property. I just read in a review on Trip Advisor that they are going to renovate in Feb 08 and boy does this place need it. Everything was moldy, banged up and run down. The room smelled, the deck was dirty (and also gave no privacy - it was tiny and you looked right at all the decks of the suites next to you). The pool which looks so good online was old with dirty tiles and the waterslide which looks like a great volcano ride is nothing. This I think is the most expensive hotel in Wailea and also the worst. Hopefully the reno changes things. While we were there however we checked out all the other hotels in the Wailea area for our next trip. We got staff at each hotel to show us the rooms and grounds. We checked out Kaanapali too which is really great but we like Wailea because it's newer, the hotel grounds more spacious, and Wailea is closest to our favourite beaches - Makena's Big Beach which is great for body surfing and Turtle Town where we swam with a 300 pound turtle! Both are 5 minutes away. The Sheraton at Kaanapali has great grounds with a fun pool and great beach and is right on Black Rock, but is not as private as the resorts in Wailea. The Marriott and Hyatt at Kaanapali are also great but there is no beach there. In Wailea our favorites are as follows: Fairmont - starts at $525 a night (vs Grand Wailea $725) and is completely renovated with beautiful pool with 140 foot waterslide, separate adult pool, all white architecture which gives it a Mediterranean feel, on site shops, fitness room, a virtually private beach (Polo Beach). The Marriott, Four Seasons and Grand Wailea all share Wailea Beach. The rooms at the Fairmont are beautiful with a separate bedroom, beautiful private deck. This is where we'll be staying next trip. Four Seasons - Gorgeous; pool is not quite as nice for kids but otherwise a fantastic looking hotel. Has tennis courts onsite too. Only problem is that they have a 200 person waitlist if you want to book over Xmas. Marriott. Also first class; my only complaint was that the suites have all tile floors and although the floor plan of the suites is very similar to the Fairmont there is no separate bedroom, just a big L shaped room so there is not any privacy if your kids are sleeping on the pull out sofa. Marriott also has a beautiful Luau (Fairmont, Grand Wailea, Four Seasons do not). I didn't want to go and do the tourist thing, but we went for the kids and it was wonderful. A delicious meal, open bar, and the show told a story of the history of Hawaii complete with Fire man, hula dancers, and a gymnast who climbed a rope 50 ft in the air and did acrobatics (representing the goddess of the mist). Luau was $264 for a family of four and worth it. We'd have been happy with Fairmont, Four Seasons, Marriott. Didn't get a chance to check out the Renaissance though. If you're looking for a condo the Ekahi Village in Wailea has wonderful grounds and is on a beach (Keawapuku?) but people told us each condo is different - some great, some rundown.

Reviews.Title: “A lot of fun but noisy!”
Reviews.Author: RealEstateDiva
Reviews.Content: Overall we had a wonderful time during both our visits. The hotel and grounds are gorgeous and the rooms are lovely with nice amenities. The pools are amazing and the beach is stunning. note... We loved our room, and had great room service and attendants, but must mention that with an 11-yr old it didn't provide much privacy with the all glass shower in bathroom, or with both the beds in the same room. Complaints... 1. For the money charged the food was average & cost of drinks ($12 mai tais) and meals in the restaurants is OUTRAGEOUS - ie... our dinner for 2 adults/1child was almost $300! May we recommend Duo or Nicks instead - these are well worth a $300 dinner. 2. No rooms ready for over 2 hours after check in time, and no luggage access during this period. It was uncomfortably hot "in limbo" as there are no air conditioned lounges to wait in in travel clothes. 3. There were VERY LOUD corporate parties going on outdoors in the open space near the chapel almost nightly. It was terrible and not very relaxing to lie in bed and listen to booming disco/rock bands at 10p at night in peaceful hawaii, especially when you're exhausted from the sun and pools and your kids are trying to sleep. 4. Pillows are awful! The worst nights sleep we've ever had in a hotel and we travel a lot! My husband drove all the way to Kahalui (over an hour there and back) the next day and purchased pillows. We visit Hawaii often & I must say with all it's grandeur, pools, and amenities the two things the GW lack are a solid sense of relaxation, and a true hawaiian spirit so prominent in other hotels nearby. ie... the bar at the pool plays rock and roll all day (like in vegas) and not hawaiian music. Honestly if it weren't for the pools we would stay at one of the more serene hotels in Wailea, but with an 11 yr old we admit we will be back for the pools.

Reviews.Title: “Simply Fabulous”
Reviews.Author: IMJustVisiting
Reviews.Content: I've stayed at the Grand Wailea in November or December for about a week each of the last three years. The hotel is simply fabulous. The rooms I've stayed in were all large and comfortable with large bathrooms with a huge bathtub and separate shower. All have had excellent ocean views. Drinking a little wine with my spouse on the lanai (balcony) while watching the sun go down and then going to sleep listening to the surf borders on a religious experience. The hotel grounds are inviting and well maintained. There is easy access to the beach and ocean, though I've tended to spend more time enjoying the numerous, connected hotel pools and various water slides. The hotel restaurants are nice though (as expected) more pricey than some excellent dining choices available in Wailea (the Cafe O'Lei, Sansei, Roy's are all highly recommended). Aloaha!

Reviews.Title: “Why Wailea?!”
Reviews.Author: LaJollaJoe
Reviews.Content: If you are looking for a high-quality, hassle free luxury family experience, keep driving past the Grand Wailea. The place is oversized, impersonal and overrated. We were told that the water feature at the Grand Wailea was not to be missed if you have children, so we booked a couple of nights there during our trip to Maui. Our room, by no means the least expensive, smelled of mildew and mold and was outdated and small. The bathroom was antiquated with none of the conveniences you would expect at a 4 star resort. But let's assume that the room quality didn't matter because your intention was to be at the beach or "water park." Well, those were a let down, too. The pool was so crowded, you could see oil from people's sunblock and beach debris in it. The lines for the slide, water elevator and rope swing were long and not worth waiting for. And forget about finding a chair, much less one in the shade. The lounge chairs were packed in rows, with people crowded together, their towels and magazines all over the place. And there were no pool attendants in site to assist. The cost of a Diet Coke? $7.50! So... we moved to the beach where we found much of the same. The Grand Wailea reminded me of Disneyland on a filled-to-capacity day. Some people swear by it, but for our famiy, we'll stick to something a little more upscale, service-oriented and serene.

Reviews.Title: “It all depends ...”
Reviews.Author: Lucy0619
Reviews.Content: We stayed here in October - a friend recommended this hotel to us when her company paid for her family to stay here. First, the hotel is beautiful. We stayed in the deluxe ocean room with stunning views of the ocean (you can easily see Molokini crater). It's so relaxing just hanging out on the lanai and taking it all in. The room was large and very clean - we loved our room. We paid about $700/night. The pool was crazy which is to be expected. Tons of kids running around and very packed. We had a good time, but for a couple, it was way too much. One day was enough. They have a great water slide, a rope swing mostly for kids, rushing rapids, lazy river, and a water elevator (not sure what the big deal is about that one). If you bring your kids, you will be a hero if you stay here. But for a couple, you will most likely want more peace and quiet! The resort fee at $25 is unreasonable. I would expect a much better valet - believe me, this will frustrate you. They charge you for valet ($15 a day) and if you choose not to pay this ridiciulous fee, you self-park down the street. Good luck finding a parking spot there. It was disappointing. Overall, we would not return as a couple. It wasn't special enough for us to match the price tag (sorry). I have no problem spending $700/night, but it has to be special. But I will end with this - if your company is paying for it and you have kids, you will probably love it.

Reviews.Title: “This is Luxury????”
Reviews.Author: JPBSanDiego
Reviews.Content: Picture this: Jumping out of bed at 6:30 a.m.to be in line at the pool by 6:45 to get a place in line. Waiting for the staff to drop the rope and RUNNING to get a chaise. Hint: go for the chair, not line up for towels first as I did. Even though I got there early I wasn't quick enough and ended up in the back row between the garbage cans and the bathrooms. I am not kidding when I say that by 7:15 all the chairs were gone.(the waterslide opens at 10:00). Don't even think about shade because there isn't any outside of the $275.00 cabanas (which were totally booked all week) or a few palapas which somehow didn't block any sun at all. They offer no umbrellas, only blazing sun all day...There really is no shade anywhere. That will, of course, only be a problem if you are lucky enough to actually get a lounge chair. There didn't seem to be enough chairs for the number of guests needing them. The lounge chairs were pretty dirty too. I had to clean the bird droppings off myself. The rooms were adequate enough and at least free from visible mold. We did smell it though. The sticky remote control and spotty bathroom handles prompted me to buy a can of Lysol to give the rooms a good disinfection. We paid over $750.00 for each of our two rooms plus they had the nerve to add $25.00 a night connecting charge. That would be to open the doors between the rooms. There also is a $25.00 per room "Resort Fee" each day to use the resort that you are paying to stay at. Go figure. Our supposed internet connection (part of the resort fee) didn't work so I was forced to use the business center at $3.50 for each 5 minutes on the computer. The game room required quarters to use most of games. All this I would expect at lesser quality property, but not at these prices. I found the nickel and dimeing for everything really objectionable. For the same money (or less) I would definately stay at a Four Seasons. Much better quality, service and value for money but of course, they don't have the water slide. As far as I am concerned, the water slide is the only reason to even set foot on this property.

Reviews.Title: “Very nice hotel for families”
Reviews.Author: familyof4inpa
Reviews.Content: Our original room was in the back of the hotel, overlooking the parking lot. We complained, and the next day we were upgraded to the napua tower with an ocean view. The tower was great. There was a free breakfast buffet with Starbuck's coffee and at least one hot food item every morning. From 5 - 6:30 there was also free appetizers and open bar in the tower. The swimming pool and beach were awesome. Our kids (7 & 10) loved it. We usually did excursions in the morning and went to the pool in the afternoon. It was easy to find shaded lounge chairs at the pool after 1 or 2:00. There was some competition in the early AM with people trying to reserve seats, but it didn't affect us. The offered us a late check out of 2:00 on the day that we left Maui, which was perfect with our 5:00 flight. Don't be afraid to ask for a better room, especially if you are a Hilton HHonors member, because although the front desk workers are not empowered to grant upgrades, their boss in the back room is willing to do so. We used points to stay at the Grand Wailea, so the cost wasn't an object for us. We would stay here again in a heartbeat.

Reviews.Title: “Go once for the pool - then you're done.”
Reviews.Author: TravelGirl29
Reviews.Content: This place is a ZOO! It's hilarious, because we were probably one of the only couples there without kids. However - I love a GREAT waterpark, and let's be frank...that's why you book this place. You need to do it once, then you probably never want to go back again. Maybe when I actually have kids and they renovate - I would reconsider! Pool - This Las Vegas sized hotel has the best pool in the country! Your kids will love you as they navigate through the lazy river, water elevator, rope swing & waterslides. All the kids were having a blast - heck, we were having a blast! They spent a TON of money landscaping the lagoon, on art work and into the waterpark area. Go to the gallery to see the Warhols & Picassos! The monstrosity of the hotel does make it tough to get around quickly though. Chairs are a pain to find near the waterpark, but easy around the adult pool. Business Centre - $3.75 for 5 minutes!!! Say goodbye to checking email...that's expensive! Food - I dug Cafe Kula. Breakfast was only around $15 with decent selection. You could also do 'cheaper' dinners like pizza, salads, spaghetti here. It wasn't AMAZING food, but it was decent. Overpriced, of course - but cheaper then the restaurants. The Bistro is a nice middle option and the poolside menu ain't bad either. Burgers were $15 or so, frozen drinks - $12 (and they were small!), virgin drinks were $8 (ouch!), $6 Shave Ice or Ice Cream. Kids were charging this stuff to their rooms like crazy!!! If you can, eat off the resort @ Cheeseburgers in Paradise or Tommy Bahama Cafe. The food is justified by the prices over at The Shops @ Wailea. Better idea - hit the Safeway up the highway and stock up on bagels, cream cheese, orange juice etc. Room - Same thoughts as others...rundown, smelly, dated and in need of a renovation. We had a 'parking lot' view over a really LOUD air conditioning unit. It was fine with the window closed, but we didn't really use our lanai because of it. The bed was comfy...but is this really a 'Waldorf Astoria' quality room? Spa - $170 plus tip for my 50 minute massage. The star here is the 'Water Spa' area with it's different baths. Never seen anything like it before - loved it and felt relaxed. Would probably not do it again, it was more like a one-time treat & I'm sure the novelty would wear off. The Road to Hana - Bring bug spray, there are mosquitos! If you get carsick, bring gravol...those roads are wind-y. Overall, the hotel itself was mediocre...the pool is the real draw. Stay for a night, then move on next door to the Four Seasons.

Reviews.Title: “run down”
Reviews.Author: desk11
Reviews.Content: We've been here 4 times before and were shocked at the condition of the hotel. The bathroom had sketchy stains, the furniture was broken and chipped, paint and wallpaper were peeling, The staff were polite but helpless. They offered three other rooms, but they were in worse condition?!? The pool was great, but again lacking basic maintenance. A $500/ night room should be clean and maintained. My advice - book one night, play in the pool 2 days and then go stay somewhere nice.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel, but needs some attention to detail to make Grand!”
Reviews.Author: catack
Reviews.Content: We just got back - yesterday 11/16 - from an eight-day stay at the Grand Wailea in Maui. We had visited the hotel three years prior in 2004 as guests but didn't stay there over night - we went to their spa, met friends, went in the pool etc. So this time when we returned to the island, we wanted to try a stay at the famed resort. Overview: The Grand Wailea is very nicely situated in Wailea, Maui. The rooms were a decent size, the amenities at the hotel were plentiful, and the beach is very nice in this area too and right outside the hotel grounds. However, when considering a top tier hotel these items would seem standard features. There were things about the Wailea that were just shy of fabulous - and for the money it costs to visit the Wailea and the reputation of the property - I would certainly say it has lost it's shine in recent years. The lobby is dramatic and impressive but there are areas when the hotel is not in the four or five star category. It is such a thin line that takes a property from "WOW, it was fabulous" to "yeah, it was nice" - much of it is in the detail of the finish and the level of service, both these areas fell short in our expectations. The Rooms: As I mentioned above, the rooms are of a decent size. We stayed in room 5083 which had it's own patio and lawn area on the 5th floor with a partial ocean view. The bed was comfortable and the linens were very nice - high thread count and all feather pillows and mattress topper. Two arm chairs, ottoman and a desk occupied space in the room - so it was quite spacious. However, the bathroom was mediocre - plain white ceramic tile, simple separate shower, granite slab tops on the vanity unit - but was without a doubt showing it's age. Cracks in the floor tile & and didn't have the WOW factor that I've seen in other "luxury" resorts like the Bellagio, Wynn and Swiss Hotel chains. The bathroom was, in short tired. There was also a really large armoire in the room that housed a large old-fashioned 32" TV. Now, I certainly didn't spend time in the room watching TV - but it was another example of the hotel's age by not having flat screens in the rooms and still using older worn furniture in the space. The door coming into the room was grubby looking; the hallways werenâ€™t always swept and clean. Regularly we would walk past dirty room service dishes that were left in the hallways, sometimes more than a day. The manicured property look was only evident in the lobby â€“ and on occasion the lobby bar was a wreck â€“ dirty glasses, plates, old magazines left lying around. The Pools: This is the one area of the resort I think people will love, particularly those visiting with children. The resort has a wonderful labyrinth of pools for the kids to play in, including water slides, water elevator, rope swing, bridges to cross etc. During our stay it was clear to see that the family traveler was provided with many ways to entertain their whole group - other hotels in the area of similar stature (Four Seasons and the Fairmont) didn't have the "Disneyland" appeal the Wailea has for many kids. The hibiscus pool for adults was lovely, quieter and more relaxing than the kidâ€™s pools and nice to use for a dip to relieve the sunâ€™s heat after lying on the loungers during the day. The Spa: I've been to the Wailea Spa a couple of times and it truly is a wonderful place.
