For the price of the treatments, given that many of the other resorts are in the same price category, you get more pampering for you dollar as they have so many facilities that are included in the treatment price. They have a whole host of baths for you to sample prior to your treatment, enzyme baths, mineral baths, Roman tubs, Japanese bath/shower and you also get a scrub included before your massage to rid you of dead skin means youâ€™ll retain your tan for longer too! :-) It was pretty crowded when I was there and that's the only downside. It's extremely popular. So you would have to wait to use some of the baths as they were always occupied, it did feel a little rushed and I don't like that the staff only provided you with a towel until you've had your scrub and are ready to go to your massage appointment â€“ usually about an hour after you first arrive. It also takes the shine off the bathing options when you can see how many people have been lounging around in the same bath water before you. Tina was my massage therapist and was very good at her craft and the treatment was relaxing and good at removing the air travel kinks I'd received earlier that day. So, overall - it's a good experience and I think 9 out of 10 people will really enjoy their visit. Food & Beverage: This property is not renowned for it's F&B services - some of the restaurants are great for lunch and Kincha the Japanese restaurant had decent sushi, the atmosphere at the facility was so-so. The bistro for lunch was nice and we had decent food there and the service from our waitress Lori - whose section we requested after our first visit - was terrific. Sashimi Ahi was really nice and fresh, as was their grilled Mahi Mahi. Room service was very well presented, breakfast in the room served on your lanai is a nice experience and the quality of the food was again decent. However, there is a 21% gratuity included in the room service and a $4 delivery charge. And - you also pay a $25 per day resort fee, which doesn't include valet parking (an additional $15 per day), all room service gratuities. We were also charged a service fee when they had to restock the mini bar - this seemed excessive. The can of Heineken from the mini bar ended up costing $8.50 including the service fee to place another replacement beer in the fridge. The pool side wait service is similar in itâ€™s pricing - and again - with everything else you pay for at this hotel, I think the management there should address where it can afford not to gouge their customers with simply outlandish charges. A small Fiji water 330ml (yes I'm sure it was that size bottle), was $7.50 - that didn't include any service fee or gratuity, just how much was being charged for the product. That type of mark-up just seems to take advantage of the customer and is unnecessary. The Check-out Bill: This area was a little worrying and follows on from the final comments in the F&B section. There's a difference in a resort like the Wailea being expensive, everyone knows that when he or she makes a reservation here and letâ€™s face it, Maui is an expensive place to go for vacation. But thereâ€™s a difference in this baseline knowledge and when the resort takes advantage of customers in completely outlandish pricing and adding charges to the bill without the knowledge of the guest. Upon check out we reviewed the bill - we'd put lots of charges on the room so wanted to see exactly what we'd spent. We had been charged for four extra days of valet parking we never used and some mini bar inaccuracies. Who reported that charge to the bill? How did they determine that cost was to go to our account? Do they just put it on every bill automatically and don't tell you about it? They did remove the charge - but there wasn't an apology and no explanation of how it got there. The total of incorrect charges on our check out bill came to $72. We spent a total of $1,700 at the resort while we were there, yet they still were trying to get the extra $72 - it seemed the hotel was always trying to get a little bit more out of it's guests, even when everyone there seemed willing to use and pay for services at the resort. Service: The way the bill was handled goes someway to demonstrate the level of service at the hotel too â€“ kind of a not too bothered, donâ€™t really care attitude; this wasnâ€™t true in every case, but more times than not Iâ€™m sad to say it was. We visited the Fairmont while we were staying at the Wailea â€“ their lobby bar is great at sunset so we strolled over there and ended up going back four times! This is the comparison Iâ€™m using against the Waileaâ€™s service. Everyone â€“ bar none â€“ at the Fairmont was delightful. The greeting coming into the property, the bar staff, spa attendant, spa therapists who we met, Nickâ€™s Fish market servers and hostess were fabulous. After weâ€™d finished our drinks at the lobby we went to the bell desk and asked for a cab back to the Wailea. The girl at the desk was lovely taking my name, asking how we enjoyed our visit to their hotel, how long we were staying, etc, etc. Then the Cadilac arrived. The Fairmont provided complimentary car service from their hotel to ours, or from their hotel to the Wailea shops, or to a local restaurant if you wanted â€“ all at NO FEE. Just part of their service â€“ and THATâ€™S the difference between a nice hotel and a WOW hotel. Because youâ€™re already paying for a great hotel that should come with great perks that shouldnâ€™t cost you extra money, it should be included at that level of resort. The Fairmont even sent the car to pick me up from the Wailea when I returned to visit their spa the next day â€œoh just call me and Iâ€™ll send the car over to get you.â€� Fabulousâ€¦.. Summing up: Oh, I wish I could say the Wailea was worth every dime and that Iâ€™d go back next time we visit â€“ because it does have the potential to be an outstanding resort. There are pros and cons to this hotel and I hope Iâ€™ve shown where each can be found. But the truth is in its price category, thereâ€™s a better experience and level of service available; weâ€™ll be going to the Fairmont.

Reviews.Title: “Not what it used to be”
Reviews.Author: laplume9254
Reviews.Content: For years, the Grand Wailea resort has been one of our favorite vacation hotelsâ€¦in fact, we stayed at the property on average two times a year. It makes me sad that I will no longer look forward to being a guest at the Grand Wailea. We arrived at the hotel on November 6th and were assigned room 4012. As we walked down the hallway with our bell man, I noticed the poor, unkempt condition of the hallway. Paint chipped, dirty walls, doors with dirty fingerprints, and filthy light fixtures were very apparent. Our room was not much better with spotted upholstery and chipped furniture. Our 4th floor grassy area was appalling. There was a paper cup lid, a straw wrapper, a dirty band-aid, cigarette butts, and weeds about six inches high. Since we were the hosts of six other couples at the hotel, we were very concerned about their rooms and complained to manager Faith Stutzman. She was very apologetic, and upgraded one of our guests to the concierge level, along with the promise that our other guests would have a â€œgood roomâ€�. The next day we spoke with manager Shannon Schiling about the condition of our patio, and he assured us that the patio garbage would be taken care of. During our five day stay, the patio was never rid of the garbage. Not just our hallway was disgusting, but the hallways of our guests were also never swept. They, too, had chipped paint with dirty walls and doors. Our dealings with the concierge, Richard, were not much better. He assured us that he cancelled our return Speedy Shuttle reservation at our request. This cancellation was never done, and Speedy Shuttle came to the hotel resulting in a needless charge to us. As I stated before, I am so disappointed in the condition of the property. I cannot imagine paying $900 over the Christmas Holiday for a room in such poor condition. This trip was embarrassing to us as we were the hosts to very important business clients. I look forward to the time when this resort is renovated, updated, and cleaned up to its previous condition.

Reviews.Title: “Freaking Awesome”
Reviews.Author: Pete495
Reviews.Content: This Resort was totally Posh! I cannot understand the negative reviews. Yes, the restaurants are expensive. Yes, they do charge a lot of money. Have you people looked around though? Everything on Maui is expensive, especially the hotels. Every hotel charges about double for drinks. If you go to a restaurant and bar off hotel premises, you will find it a lot cheaper. It is not just the Grand Weilea that charges extra for everything. We stayed at two Hotels on our stay, one which was less stars than the other, and both were comparable when it came to restaurant food and drink. My wife and I are middle class, and we stayed at this resort for 5 days. When we got to the resort, we checked ourselves in and parked our own car to save a little money. We parked our own car everyday, because they charge you money per day to use valet. When we were checked in, we were given a choice for an upgrade, either a king bed or two queens with an ocean view. We chose the ocean view, and what a spectacular view it was. Very Nice! We were very Pleased! The Parking lot is further away if you park yourself, but it was worth a few dollars saved. All resorts charge extra for their daily resort fee, and this is extra in addition to your trip fee, whether it is expedia, unitedvacations, or whatever, so expect it when you go. The Service: Excellent As said above, all you had to do was ask, and you were accomodated. We did not like the puffy pillows in the rooms, so we asked for flatter pillows in our room from housekeeping, and were immediately accomodated. On the beach, staff would help you grab chairs, give you as many towels as you wanted, and it was not too much trouble to ask for anything. Water was free all over the premises. they had tanks w/ cups everywhere. Everyone said hello, or Aloha, or Mahalo. The Room: We were upgraded to Oceanview with two Queens. The view was amazing, and the bathroom came with a two person soaking tub, and a glass enclosed shower, which could easily fit 3 persons if you wanted. Mini bar and frig accompanied the room, and it was very tempting not to use the mini bar, but it was just too expensive. We went to the Weilea village, and were able to buy liqour and beer for less than half the price of the mini bar contents. One should expect the mini bar to be high priced though. There are complimentary robes in the room. the beds are simply plushible comfortability. The Lanai comes with two chairs and a table. The room comes with free internet via internet cable provided. Housekeeping comes twice a day, once in the morning to clean, and once in the evening to provide turn down service. I suggest leaving a couple dollars tip at least, and they will treat you right. Bell men insisted upon helping with the luggage, which we felt was very nice even though we were pretty much doing it ourselves anyway. They also have the Napua Tower, which has its own wing with it's own continental breakfast, and its own Hour d oevers and wine nightly, and also its own concierge. obviously we did not stay here, but passed by it on the way to our room everyday, and wondered about its amenities. it is available for extra dollars of course. The Service: Above Par: Now if you rent one of the cabanas for a cost on the lawn, you will have someone to wait on you and they will bring you frozen grapes all day, but we did not spend the money on the cabana. If you ask the waiter or waitresses for drinks while you are sitting in chairs though, they will gladly accomodate. We did not order too many drinks though because they are really expensive, which we knew going in (12 dollars/mixed drink). If you didn't know this going in, I guess I could see how you could react poorly, but when you go to a resort this size, you should really do a little research. We used chairs on the beach at no cost. Really, the cabanas were not worth the money unless you have a medical condition that prevents you from being in the sun. The Spa: All we heard about when we were at the Resort was how great the Spa was. We did not use it, but apprently it is rated one of the best around. We thought about it several times, but did not want to spend the extra money since we were spending so much already. Beach and Pools: Beach is rated best in the nation many times. I have even seen it on the Travel Channel at Home. Snorkel excursions visit nearby because of all the turtles, and because of it being such a great snorkel site. The beach is pretty much immaculate, with lawn and laying chairs available, nice white sand and fairly calm waters. The pool is in itself just freaking amazing. There are a bunch of pools on a slope, and all are connected by several waterslides, two big ones being the main attractions. Between the two big waterslides is the worlds only water elevator, which takes you to the top of one of the big waterslides. We understood what we paid when we saw and rode in the water elevator. There is an adult habiscus pool which is luke warm rather than the cold water pools near the bottom. There are two adult hot tubs near the adult hibiscus pool, and there is also a massage therapist near the hibiscus pool which is avaiable for a charge. there are probably a total of 5-7 hot tubs, and also several pools. there is a kiddy beach for the kids right off of the regular beach, which is made to be safer, and is really a pool/beach for the children. There are lifeguards all around. The Land: They have about 15 million dollars put into their art work. They have tours of the resort for free just to view their art work if you like that sort of thing. They also have tours for the Flowers and landscape where they explain all that to you if you like that sort of thing also. Eating: We ate and drank very rarely at the hotels we stayed at because it was so expensive. The other hotel we stayed at was the Sheraton. It was also very very nice, and we would go back to either hotel, but the drinking and eating at both places was expensive, so we planned ahead wear to eat and drink by using Maui books bought in different stores. We sprang a little and ate breakfast once at the Grand Weilea in the Grand Dining Room the last morning we were there. My wife is a big breakfast fan, so we tried it. It was $28 pp, and even though it was a huge breakfast, and it included a lot of food, it still was not worth the dollars. That is why we planned ahead to eat off of the resorts. Other: Most people we talked to did not leave the resort, but we knew better. We did the Road to Hana, The Pipwai trail, another hike walk, and viewed many of the beaches North of Kannapali. We also did a Trilogy excurion for our Snorkel trip, and it took us to Molokini, where the water was clear about 50 feet down. We both agreed we had never seen water as clear before, and we have both snorkeled a couple of times before. Trilogy was awesome, fed us breakfast and lunch, and snacks in between, and was always asking us if we needed more to drink. I highly recommend Trilogy! You will need a car on the island if you are going off the resort. It is a negative if you do not get out of your hotel room. If you are not squeemish in the Car, do the Road to Hana, and go to the 7 Sacred Pools, and walk the Pipiwai trail (2 miles one way) Follow the pics and paragraphs in Maui Revealed. It was definitely our little blue book on this trip. Overall: If you go to Maui, I highly recommend that you do you reserach, and plan ahead. Otherwise, you will feel like a lot of others on this site that you were nickel and dimed beyond belief. If you don't expect to spend more than you think, then you will feel like you were shorted. We had an awesome Vacation staying at two hotels that were awesome. We expected to pay more than what we did up front, so expect that from the beginning. Email me for your questions or for pictures. I have a ton of them.

Reviews.Title: “Grand Wailea was incredible!!!”
Reviews.Author: katem07
Reviews.Content: We booked our vacation through United Vacation and ended up paying much less for our rooms. We stayed 5 nights at the Sheraton Black Rock and 5 nights at the Grand Wailea. At first we were sad to leave the Sheraton after such a great stay there, but we were very pleasantly surprised by the Grand Wailea especially after all of the negative reviews that it recieved. We arrived at noon (we had to check out of the Sheraton at 11am) and were planning on just relaxing on the beach until our room was available. To our surprise not only was our room available but we had been upgraded to an oceanview room. The view from our room was incredible! Our room was very clean and very comfortable. The huge bathtub was great....especially after our trip from Hana. The beds were very comfortable, our only complaint was the pillows were too fluffy. We asked for flatter pillows the second day and we were happier after that! The pools were crazy, the slides brought out the kid in me. The beach was beautiful. Usually started the day at the beach and then moved to the pools in the afternoon. We never had a problem getting a chair. There was a variety of people at the hotel. Alot of familes with children, but it didn't bother us at all. It was actually kind of neat to see them having a ball on the slides. We did not eat at the hotel much. Had lunch twice. It was overpriced, but so are most hotels in Maui. We got the breakfast buffet the last day and regretted it. The food was okay, but for $28 I expected more. We found great places to eat my scanning the internet for places and viewing their menus and prices. We ate at inexpesive places most of the time and then treated oursleves to a few nice dinners. Mama's Fish House was the best, but I could not afford to eat like that every night! The staff was very accomodating throughout our stay. The day we checked out we had asked about checking out late due to the fact that our flight didn't leave until 10:30pm. The staff informed us that we would not be able to check out late, but that they would provide a room for us to use before leaving for the flight. The room that they provided was greatly appreciated! We spent all day on the beach and were able to shower and change before our 12 hrs flying! I would recommed the Grand Wailea to anyone that I know. I honestly don't how people can find fault with this hotel. I was surprised my the negative reviews and have decided that the people writing them are rich snobs. My middle class ass thought it was fine!

Reviews.Title: “Average hotel full of bugs and smelling of mold”
Reviews.Author: nordicman2007
Reviews.Content: We stayed here on hh honors points. For 80,000 points per night , we were extemely disappointed with the rooms. We had to move three times! All of our rooms smelled of mold and had ants in the bathroom...after being upgraded to a ocean view we decided to just try and enjoy our stay. The grounds are nice, pool areas are impressive. Those are the good points. The extremely overpriced food ($25 for a burger?), inattentive front desk staff and overcrowded parking ( we had to park at the shops of wailea mall down the street and walk back!) ensured we would never stay here again. We stayed on maui last year at the Diamond hawaii resort/spa and Kea lani hotels and experienced clean, comfortable rooms and superior service compared to the very much non grand wailea. And keep in mind this review is coming from someone who paid nothing for his room! It was free with our points....Check out the diamond resort or the fairmont kea lani, you wont be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: “Great vacation; decent hotel”
Reviews.Author: ASU_Sundevils
Reviews.Content: My wife, daughter (age 7), and I stayed at the Grand Wailea for seven nights (10/20-27) as part of my daughter's two week fall break. We booked the vacation in December 2006 when Hawaiian Airlines offered exceptional non-stop fares between San Diego and Maui. We paid $1,033 for the three round-trip tickets (inclusive of all taxes). After we decided that Maui would be the destination my wife said, "I want to stay where Oprah brought her staff." I looked into the Grand Wailea and immediately rejected it due to the outrageous cost of the rooms. But my wife persisted so I dug deeper into the internet and found Great Hawaii Vacations, which had a rate for the Grand Wailea that was significantly cheaper than every other place I checked. We booked an "Ocean Queen / Queen", which is quoted on the hotel web site as $855 per night plus tax and resort charge. The rate I got was $480/night including tax, which would be an even $500/night including the resort charge. My dealings with Great Hawaii were great and I highly recommend them with this caveat - you will not receive any Hilton Honors points for your stay (including incidentals) if you book through an outside agent. This is a Hilton Honors policy and it is strictly enforced. The hotel front desk team knows the policy and so do the Hilton Honors customer service staff. A few months before the trip I went to Priceline and, for giggles, bid $30/day for a convertible. Much to my pleasant surprise the bid was accepted by Hertz. You must rent a convertible while on Maui - just trust me on this one - and try Priceline first. We had a great flight on Hawaiian into Maui - the plane left San Diego at 8:30 a.m. and arrived on-time. The airport is easy to get through, and after an acceptable wait we had our luggage and were off to the rental car pickup. Getting out of the airport is a breeze and there are well-marked signs that indicate the route to Wailea. Of course, I had directions from Google Maps, which were very accurate. In fact, before the trip I made maps to every place I thought I might want to go, and all the maps were good. Because we arrived at the hotel around noon it was too soon to check-in. The valet staff greeted us with a very warm aloha - we decided to use the valet during the trip (an extra $17/night but well worth it in my opinion). We found the valet service to be exceptional throughout the stay. We rarely had to wait more than a minute or two for our car, they were very friendly, and also offered great suggestions as to where we could eat (and giving great directions). We were also greeted with nice, fresh leis. We were told at the front desk that we would not be able to check-in until 3:00 or 4:00, which was a bit discouraging given that we were tired, esepcially our 7-year-old. We were able to initiate the check-in process so that all we needed to do was pickup our keys. It was at this time that I noticed we had been upgraded to a "Deluxe Ocean Queen / Queen", which is listed at $980/night plus tax and resort charge. I did not ask to be upgraded - this was already in the system. The front desk took our cell-phone number and told us we would be called as soon as the room was ready. I'll add here that the front desk staff is very friendly. We checked our luggage, my daughter pulled her bathing suit from her suitcase, and we decided to explore. The front door of the resort is nice but, as many have noted, it is a Disney version of Hawaii. The Wailea area is essentially a desert and the lush tropical setting you see is very much a product of a huge landscaping team and a lot of irrigation. Still, it looks beautiful and helps to set the mood. The hotel lobby is very nice and open as are most of the larger Hawaiian resorts. I was not impressed with the much bally-hooed art collection. We walked to the pool area and, after about 30 minutes, it was just too much tempation for my daughter. We got wristbands (a different color every day to keep out the riff-raff) and my daughter went swimming. The place was absolutely packed. It was a Saturday in late October when school is in session and this place was crawling with kids. We had to look quite hard to find even a single empty beach chair. [Aside - My daughter attends elementary school in the only district in San Diego county that has a fall break. I asked many parents how they managed to come to Maui and all of them said, "We pulled our kids out of school." Do not expect to come to the Grand Wailea in the off-season and see a limited number of kids. However, I saw very few junior-high aged kids, and virtually no high school or college age kids. The place is also crawling with honeymooners.] But back to the beach chair hunt - all you have read is true. The pool opens at 7:00 and the really good spots are taken soon thereafter, but the hotel staff does patrol the area and I saw many instances of chairs being given to other people because they (the chairs) had been unattended for at least an hour. The cabanas and chairs with the built-in umbrellas are a complete rip-off. This hotel is part of the Waldorf-Astoria collection, as is the Arizona Biltmore. The Grand Wailea people need to go to the Biltmore (or any nice hotel on the Las Vegas strip) and see what a cabana is supposed to look like (and cost). After a short amount of swimming it was clear that our daughter was exhausted. I went back to the front desk to check on our room - it still wasn't ready but another "Deluxe Ocean Queen / Queen" was available. We took it and were soon in our room relaxing. There is absolutely nothing special about the rooms. There were no weird smells or bugs, but the rooms are definitely no better than what you'll find in any three-star property. The hotel itself is not in tip-top shape as there are scuff marks all over the exterior walls, cracks in tile, messy landscaping in some areas, etc. If you want to see a beautiful hotel that lives up to its rates walk over to the Four Seasons (more on that one later). The rooms are much larger than a standard hotel room yet the bathroom only has one sink. As others have noted, there were many flaws in the room - it is time for a renovation. The TV is not a flat screen, which is what I expect now in a nice hotel. I was disappointed that there was no bottled water waiting for (as is custom for Hilton Honors guests), and this is the first Hilton I have stayed at in at least ten years where I didn't get a paper every morning. [Aside - There are several papers from the mainland available in the hotel sundry store; however, they come one day late and cost about five times what you pay on the mainland, e.g., LA Times = $2.50]. We were on the 8th floor of the northern-most building with a spectacular, unobstructed view of the ocean, Molokini, etc. Is it worth the extra money? No. Much has been said about the outrageous cost of food at this hotel - believe it! However, nobody is holding a gun to your head and forcing you to eat at the hotel. Just up the road a couple of miles is Kihei where you will find any number of places to eat that are extremely reasonable and, as a bonus, filled with locals. Try Kihei Cafe for starters - you'll wake up at 5:00 a.m. the first few days due to the time change and this place will get you started off right. You'll pay less for a full breakfast for two here than you will for a single item at Grand Wailea. We only ate breakfast at Grand Wailea's restaurant (Grand DIning Room) on the last morning. The service was good, the view was great, the food was OK, and the price was high. We grabbed ala carte a couple of times at Cafe Kula - you can save a bit of money this way but it is still expensive. Surprisingly, the similar restuarant at Fairmont Kea Loni (a 10-15 minute walk south on the ocean-front boardwalk) is better quality and less expensive. I would steer far away from Big Wave cafe in Kihei - one of the worst breakfasts I've ever had. For lunch we typically ate poolside at Grand Wailea and, yes, paid dearly for the pleasure. The service isn't bad, the food is OK, and the prices are consistent with what you pay at any high-end resort. The burgers are cooked on a big bbq right next to the pool so you know things are fresh. A burger will cost you $15 but it is only an extra quarter for cheese and an extra quarter on top of that for bacon. The drinks are expensive ($12 for a mai tai) but they pack a wallop. I highly recommend the swim-up bar. It is fun and the service is fantastic. We saw the same bartender every day - he looked like a cross between Andy Warhol and Ed Begley, Jr. Same prices for drinks as anyplace else around the pool but a great atmosphere. The slides are fun, the pools are fun, and things are actually a lot quieter than you'd expect given the number of people. I had no problem falling asleep in my chair each day. One quibble - the pool temperature could be higher. I would guess the temperature to be no higher than 80 degrees - I prefer warmer. The ocean/beach in front of the hotel is nice - the water is fairly calm and the temperature was about 78 degrees. There is some fun snorkeling immeidately north of the hotel beach (about 100 feet) where a small reef juts out from the shoreline. It was crawling with fish. You need to do your snorkeling early in the morning before the winds come up and make things choppy. Our routine was breakfast, pool at 7:00 to get chairs, snorkel, and then back to pool. If you snorkel, and you must, I have two recommendations. First, get your snorkel equipment at Snorkel Bob's in Kihei. The quality of the equipment is first rate, the price is right (we paid about $80 for a week-long rental for all three of us), and the service is exceptional. Second, you've got to take a trip to Molokini crater. For me this was the highlight of the vacation. In my mind there is only one way to take this trip and that is the sunrise cruise on the Molokini Express from Kai Kanani Charters. You can find them on the web or in the Maui Prince hotel. The trip leaves at 6:30 sharp from the beach in front of the Maui Prince. Why this trip? The boat is brand new; the crew is fantastic; you are only 15 minutes away from the crater; the early hour means the ocean water is smooth as glass; and you will be done snorkleing before any of the other boats arrive. Let me repeat that - on this cruise you will have the entire crater to yourself. On our way back we passed at least seven huge boats full of people - it was hard not to feel smug. The charter includes continental breakfast and a stop at Turtle Town, where we saw incredible sea turtles. Another recommendation - do the Old Lahaina Luau. We actually did not do a luau while on Oahu two years ago as our hotel concierge said, "Honestly, if you want to see a real luau you've got to go to Maui." Even on Maui there are cheesy luaus - not the Old Lahaina luau. The service was incredible, the setting was great, the pig pulled from the emu is the one you eat that evening (unlike at most luaus), the drinks were stiff, and the entertainment was fantastic. The number of performers is quite large - at least two dozen and the music is all performed live (two different sets of musicians). Further, the entertainment is true to Hawaii - don't go expecting to see swords and fire - that isn't Hawaii. Lahaina is a big tourist trap - how many t-shirt shops, art galleries, jewelry stores, and sunglass shops does a town need? But go for the luau! As a bonus, the drive from Wailea is great! We didn't eat a single dinner at the Grand Wailea - we ate three dinners at the Four Seasons, including the Lobby Lounge, Ferreros (spelling?), and Spago. The mai-tai I had a Ferreros was the best I've ever had. I highly recommend Ferreros - the setting is magnificent, the food is great, and the service is outstanding. The Lobby Lounge and Spago are what you expect from Four Seasons but Ferreros was a notch above. Indeed, I would much prefer to stay at Four Seasons or Fairmont Kea Loni but having a seven-year-old makes the Grand Wailea the better choice. The weather was incredible the entire trip - not a drop of rain or even the threat of rain, and very limited clouds. I would go back to Maui again tomorrow if there weren't so many other places I want to visit, e.g., Big Island and Kauai.

Reviews.Title: “Poolahpalooza”
Reviews.Author: Sassypants01
Reviews.Content: We stayed here & the Four Seasons during our week on Maui. It was our 1st visit. We definitely felt the Four Seasons was superior in every respect. But that said, the Grand Wailea has a fabulous pool system & every kid there was having a ball. The lobby is truly lovely. We only ate the breakfast buffet & it was quite good, but we also went down to Kehei Caffe for a local experience at significantly less expense. GW has several restaurants that look great; we chose to eat off property to see various sights. The beach is fantastic, only the lack of support to secure beach chairs was kind of a drag. While service was not excellent, it was also very polite. We did have to wait 3 hrs for our room (we arrived early & were offered nowhere to change for the beach, only told several times they'd call us which was frustrating because we thought that meant they were hurrying to accomodate us & 20 minutes beyond check in we had to request a manager to get a room) Despite this, the property is just beautiful & our kids loved the pools. Our room was quite nice & very clean. The valet service was efficient & polite. So we had no specific complaints. We even liked our experience, but the thing is, we are not particularly compelled to go back. We might....we might not. It's just that for the money, it didn't feel like it was well spent. While the Four Seasons felt like a bargain & cost much more. Hope this makes sense. If you're going soon...you'll have a wonderful time. Maui is fantastic! Aloha!

Reviews.Title: “Moldy”
Reviews.Author: tarbus
Reviews.Content: Checked into a very busy hotel with a long wait. But that was okay. Went to the room it spelled like mold and carpet was damp. So we requested a new room. The second room was still musty but not wet. Woke up the next day feeling congested and we requested a new room. Shannon the manager said I will take care of it enjoy the day. We did great pool, beach, slides etc. However the busiest hotel in Maui. At 5 I went to get the new room it also smelled like mold I told Shannon we need a room that is clean he took me to a newlt remodled tower which was better but then insisited on an additional 250.00 when we were already paying 500.00 a night. At this point I told him to cancel the rest of my stay and we went to the Key Lani which is down the street and had large suites ocean front for the same price very clean nice staff. Grand Waleia also charges you for everything. For example If you want a refigerator 25.00. The hotel is very old so if you are interested in a great pool, musty rooms this is the place. During my 3 week stay we went to three other resorts that were awesome. Grand Waleia was the Grand Dump.

Reviews.Title: “Nothing short of perfect!”
Reviews.Author: Donny1113
Reviews.Content: My husband and i (first time Hawaii visitors) stayed at the Grand Wailea from Sept. 1 thru 5 of 2007. I traded my Disney Vacation Club Points for a fee of $95, i had to bank and borrow quite a few points to get an ocean view room but it was well worth it! The trip started off terribly, we were flying from NY-LAX-OGG, our flight from NY to LAX was fine, little did we know that we would be layed over @ LAX for 11 1/2 hrs, yes thats right almost a 12 hr flight delay, it was the most miserable experience ever, not to mention that my car rental company wouldnt stay opend for us THANX ALAMO! anyway, once we got to the GW @ about 1am, there were about 3 employees running the show. The min. we stepped into the lobby, we had forgotten all about our terrible experience, the flight and all our troubles had just melted away, instantly. The lobby is all open air, with lush foliage all over the place, gorgouse art, (and im not an art freek at all). We were greeted with a beautiful lei and an upgrade to the Napua Tower, wich entitled us to complimentary breakfast daily and apps & cocktails in the evening, it was also a gated community, where the only access was with your room key, i nearly cryed when she told us we were upgraded, i felt like we had hit lotto, LOL. Anyway, we got to our room, they had set us up with ice and turned the TV on for us. This room was amazing, everything looked brand spanking new, flat screen plasma tv, crisp white linnens, large bathroom, great living space, beatiful furniture both in the room and out on the lanai, we had a view of the courtyard and Molokini Crater in the distance, it was picture perfect! We were very close to the lounge that was serving breakfast, they had a nice arrangement of muffins, breads, fruits, cereal, yogurt, Starbucks Coffee, eggs, meats, cheeses, they basically had everything, and you can take your plate and eat out on the lanai, warining, the birds are NOT shy, LOL. We went down to the pool/waterpark, how amazing. We spent the whole day running around like kids, i was waterlogged by the time we got back to the room. We spent some time at the adult pool that was nice for a break from the kids but i loved the activity pool, we took a ride on the water elevator, it was a blast, the water slides were legitamate waterslides not some cheesey slides. We sat by the adult pool and ordered some lava flows, they were really good, but very pricy, but hey your on Maui and staying in Wailea for god sakes-u gotta expect that! Service was second to none, i had called up the concierge to get restaurant suggestions, the guy didnt even turn his nose up or show attitude when i told him "something not too pricey", he gave us a great suggestion and we had a wonderful dinner at Longhies, it was walking distance right at the shops @ Wailea, not to be confused with the Wailea Shops. Shops @ Wailea are up the road just a bit, there is a short cut through the tiki torches at the entrance to the hotel. We did not valet the car, they had a parking garage that was the next right after the main entrance, you had acess with your room key and it was free of charge and there was also a back entrance to the hotel from there, again, there was no snobbery when we asked if there was a garage we can park ourselves. The beach fronting the hotel was awesome as well, not crowded, the water was clean, mostely calm except for the far left side where there is supposed to be good snorkeling. If i went to Wailea again, i would never stay anywhere else, this place was spectacular and i would suggest it to ANYONE! Hope u enjoyed reading my review, please ask me any questions!

Reviews.Title: “The Grand Five and Dime”
Reviews.Author: earthtraveler2007
Reviews.Content: Who runs this place - Montgomery Burns? There were many times my wife and I muttered to ourselves, "You cheap [--]" Charging for housekeeping? Charging for a lousy beach umbrella? Graciously providing packaged processed coffee, and NOT Kona? At THESE prices. CHEAP CHEAP CHEAP! OK, the pool areas are pretty cool and well designed, and if you're looking for a Snazzy Jazzy resort, to LOOK AT, this is it. But the "Upscale Resort" appeal stops there. It's not as if there was bad service, but it ceratinly wasn't great. You'd get the same at a Ramada. The sunsets on the beach are beautiful, but why not enjoy them with a $7 beer or a $14 drink? The place is relatively clean, but it's obvious nothing has been done since it was first built. It's aging and it shows it. Do NOT order room service. The food is God awful. In fact, with the one exception of the PU PU platter at Humu Humu, the food was mediocre at best, and just plain BAD. Eat off sight if you can. The buffet at Kincha, the Japanese restautant was OK, but on par with what one would find at a Holiday Inn, NOT the Grand Wailea at 400 bucks a night. Food at these places should be top notch - NO exception. The "GW" is just not worth it. Think of paying full price for a top of line Mercedes and then hearing, "Would you like an engine?" ; "I'm sorry, door handles are extra." ; "Oh, you want tires... there's a charge for that." I'm sure the owners and managment of the Grand Wailea are satisfied with their hotel, but this nickel and dime nonsense and sub par service will catch up with them.

Reviews.Title: “The,Good, the Bad and the Ugly”
Reviews.Author: akakenny1
Reviews.Content: I'm a chronic Maui vacationer! I just returned from a 9 days stay at the GW (Oct 5-13). Our family of 4 with 2 girls 6 and 4 has more fun on Maui than any of the other Hawaiian islands. This is my 12th Visit to Maui and my 3rd stay at the GW. I loved the Resort so much so that 4 years ago I bought a memebrship to the GW that gives you 50% off the rack rate on all the rooms. If you're budget conscious Maui and the GW is a expensive place to visit, but if you're looking for a fun hawaiian getaway with an expectation of higher average cost then there is no other place to go on your vacation. As a season traveler I've stayed in many 4-5 star hotels in all of the Hawaiian Islands ( 4seasons Hualalai, KapaluaRitz, Kaanapali Hyatt, Hyatt Kauai, Marriott Kauai, Kaanapali Westin, Fairmont Kea Lani, Fairmont Orchid, PrinceVille, Turtle Bay) so I have a good refernce point to compare the quality of the resorts. So here are the Good, The Bad and The Ugly: The Good The GW is a gorgeous resort on one of the most beautiful stretch of beach in the world. The sunsets are dramatic and breath taking. I usually take a beach chair with the wife and kids and just take in the view almost every night. The grounds are kept for the most part clean and well manicured around the resort building. The open Lobby is an inviting tropical setting with millions of dollars worth of art and scultures. And of course the famous pools, pools, and more pools!!! The GW is either a hotel with an awesome water slide park or a water slide park with great hotel! The pools are is divided in 3 sections --the upper small pools, the main pools with a sand bottom childs area and the adult pool. Each pool area has its own vibe and types of people. There are 3 small pools in the upper section and has mainly familys with children that can swim and want to be near the smaller slides. The main pool is where most of the guest congregate. It tends to be most crowded and noisiest ,but if you're enjoying the pools like the others you won't notice the noise. The Adult pool allows those over 18 but I've seen some "tweenager" inhabiting the pool at times. This is great place to read and have quiet converstion--very relaxing. To cap it all off the slides are what make the GW a uniquely fun place. There are 2 fast and furious slides and 5 smaller slides the little ones and big kids would love comming down on. My kids developed fins after spending most of their days in the pools. During the peak summer season chairs are taken up ealy in the mornings but we didn't have problems finding a seat during our Oct stay. The Grand Dinning is a good but expensive place to dine. I highly recommend that you try their Sunday brunch buffet, but their breakfast buffet is just OK. Kincha is there Japanese themed restaurant and it's quite good but expensive. My wife and I tried their Weekend sushi buffet and it was fabulous. For relatively cheap and good eats try the Kula cafe for informal dining --the average cost is anywhere from $7-$14 per meal. The Bad Expect to pay for extras. Be expected to be nickled and dimed with various resort fees, taxes and use of ameneties (extra small fridge was $25). The Cabanas, shaded private lounge chairs, and beach umbrellas cost extra and the price is a exorbitent. The 4 Season next door will give you all these for free. The pool area needs some updating and repairs on their cracked tiles in the pools and walk ways. The Ugly During our stay they had a large convention about 400 people. They basically took over the resort and turned the GW into a frat party/spring break. They were mostly young, tatooed , drunk, loud, obnoxiuos and seemed like they never stayed in a nice resort before. One of the concierge told me that some of them were sent home for damagaing their room--what is this spring break in orlando at a Motel 6!!! Every morning the entire place was deserted and we had the entire pool to ourselves but then at 1pm when the convention got out there was wall to wall people in the pool with beers in their hand. The atmoshere was not condusive for families while the conventioneers where out. The Conclusion. The mostly good out ways the bad and ugly. I would ask the reservation desk if you plan vacation at the GW if there is a large convention during your stay and if there is one I would consider another date. All in all, my kids had a great time and because of that we will be back for our 4th time soon. Have an expection to pay extra for ameneties--Maui is an expensive place to visit. Tips Along trying the great dinning establishment (Spago, Roys, Mamma's fish house, many others) you need to try some of the local fare. I love hawaiian mixed plate ( meat side dish, with two soops of rice and hawaiian macaroni salad) and there are few good place that servce the locals. Try "Da Kitchen" in Kihei, L and L (various locations) and Aloha Mixed Plate in Lahaina ( great and inexpesive outdoor dinning). The food is good and cheap--under $10 in all these place. Enjoy!

Reviews.Title: “Lovely resort.”
Reviews.Author: PoolboyDetroitMI
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed here from September 29 - October 6, 2007. We stayed in a great room and we loved the ocean view. I was happy with the size of the bathroom and the cleanliness of it and the room. We thought the hotel grounds were lovely and well maintained. We loved our morning walks along the ocean path. We spent most of our time at the Hibiscus pool. We are early risers so most mornings I had the pool to myself even though the hotel was full. My husband tried the beach and said it was fantastic. There were plenty of lounges located throughout the pool areas. The bar staff were attentive but not obtrusive. We ate at the breakfast buffet several mornings. Service was ok and the buffet items were as well. The made to order omelettes were good. Do not leave your food unattended or it will be attacked by the sparrows. There are many dining options located near the hotel. We enjoyed dinner at Joe's and pizza at Matteo's. Both are within walking distance. Our favourite meals were at Mama's Fish House (on the North Shore) which is about half an hour away by car. I enjoyed the nearby shops which include high end shopping as well as reasonably priced souvenirs. Overall we enjoyed our stay and would be happy to return.

Reviews.Title: “Gone downhill”
Reviews.Author: KaiHonolulu
Reviews.Content: Ever since Hilton took over ownership of this fine resort- they have been booking "groups". The once "quiet" pool area is now a haven for young drunkards -whoopin' and hollerin '- disturbing the guest s who have shelled out big bucks for a quiet day at the pool. If you're looking for a high end vacation that won't disappoint - go to the Four Seasons down the road.

Reviews.Title: “Favorite Hotel in Maui!”
Reviews.Author: Vickie
Reviews.Content: My husband and I have been to Maui 5 times. We've stayed at the Hyatt and Westin in Kaanapali and the Four Seasons, Fairmont and most recently, the Grand Wailea in Wailea. We both favoured the Grand Wailea the most. We loved the fact that this hotel is situated between the shops of Wailea and the Four Seaasons. I love shopping at the shops, we like eating at the restaurants in the Shops of Wailea and we loooove having dinner at Spago and Ferraros which are both restaurants located at the Four Seasons, and we love the breakfast buffet at the Four Seasons. We don't love staying at the Four Seasons because we find the grounds aren't that large and so when it's full, it feels like people are on top of each other. Also we find there are tons of babies and very small children at the Four Seasons. However, I'm not sure that we would have loved the Grand Wailea so much if we were there in the summer or at Christmas time when there are lots of children. But we plan to check it out anyways for Christmas 2008. Some other things we loved about the Grand Wailea was our deluxe ocean view room, the breakfast buffet, the lounge for drinks, the lobby, oceanfront cabanas, and the service. We'll definitely return to the Grand Wailea!

Reviews.Title: “Amazing!!”
Reviews.Author: travelingtheworld-7
Reviews.Content: This hotel is amazing!! It is over the top beautiful!! Everything from the pools, to the landscaping to the rooms were all awesome! They also had very friendly staff that went above and beyond. I highly recommend this hotel to all!!

Reviews.Title: “Fabulous!!!!!!!!!!!!!!”
Reviews.Author: LouisianaBeachbum
Reviews.Content: My husband and I love to travel to beach destinations and our most recent trips include Sandals - Whitehouse Jamaica and Atlantis-Bahamas. We've always dreamed of visiting Hawaii and we decided to book a trip May 17, 2007 for 10 days. We started our trip by visiting the Big Island, Hawaii for 3 days and then went to Maui & stayed at the Grand Wailea Resort Hotel & Spa for the remainder of our trip. I did alot of research prior to the trip & watched several Discovery Channel shows on Hawaii which is how I discovered the Grand Wailea. We rented a car on both islands (I highly suggest this & be sure to get a navigational system with the car). When we arrived, we were greated with a lei (which was nice as we had not received one at the airport which disapointed me) and were escorted to the front desk for checkin. During my research, I discovered that the hotel has a "secret hotel" within the hotel which is used by many celebritys and bigwigs :). We had reserved a regular ocean front room, but I teased the desk clerk by asking if our room was in this secret part of the hotel (which was definately out of our price range). To my delight, he upgraded us to one of these rooms. Wasn't that NICE!!!!! Let me just say that it was FABULOUS!!! We had the most beautiful bathroom with pink marble and the room was terrific with a wonderful ocean view and private balcony. Also, we received complimentary breakfast each morning (no crowds) and cocktails in the evening. What a wonderful treat! The property was beautiful, the pool was amazing and we never had trouble finding lounge chairs. The beach was nice but the water was rather cold so we stayed at the pool. We ate at a couple of restaurants which were very nice & delicious but rather pricey. The boutiques at the hotel are great!!! I bought a very pretty bathing suit (which was altered for a small price and delivered to my room the same day), pretty beaded flip-flops, and my husband bought me a FABOULOUS purse! They also had artists visit the property on certain days and their works were truly beautiful! We are divers and we booked an excursion that went to Molokini and Turtle Island - it was wonderful! The water clarity was amazing but be sure to take the early morning (6:00 a.m) dive as Molokini gets very busy in the afternoon and the water clarity diminishes in the afternoon due to the tradewinds. The dives were great - we saw sea turtles (HUGE), stingrays, small sharks, blowfish, eels, large sea urchins and great corals. We also booked a tour for the road to Hana and were very glad we did (rather than driving ourselves)! The driver was terrific and we learned so much about the culture and history of Hawaii. Hana is a full day excursion and the views are simply breathtaking. Definately try to visit the seven pools - we didn't go in the water but the VIEWS - wow!!! There are also vendors at certain parts of the road that sell pretty seashell necklaces. We found that the "Elvis" lady sold the prettiest necklaces, but don't ask her about We discovered Lahaina and loved it! It's a nice little town about 1/2 hour drive from GW. We bought some wonderful artwork from a Christian Lassan gallery and some beautiful tahitian pearls and we loved BJ's Pizza (ate there 2 times). We also bought some darling clothes for my 2 year old daughter and the prices were great! I can't say enough about Lahaina!! We also were able to book the Old Lahaina Luah! TIP - you must book this in advance of your vacation. When we arrived at the hotel, I tried to book this luah and they informed us that it was sold out for the entire week and there was a waiting list of 70 people. I asked to be placed on the list anyway and 4 days later I still had not received word of availability so I called back on my own. The representative informed me that they were still sold out and asked if I was on the waiting list. I told her yes and gave her my last name but she couldn't find it and that was that. After I persisted, she finally located my name and told me we could come the next evening but no promises! Long story short, we were able to get in and really enjoyed the show and the food - I definately recommend this and it's in Lahaina, so you could go in the early afternoon, eat at BJ's, shop and then catch the show that evening! I highly recommend staying at the Grand Wailea. The staff was great and the property is secluded and beautiful! It was a once in a lifetime trip for us and the staff made it extra special for us! ENJOY!!!!!!!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Thumbs Down for the Grand Wailea”
Reviews.Author: going2maui2006
Reviews.Content: We went to check-in early, figuring that a room wouldn't be available quite yet but wanted to make sure that everything was in the system and ready for us when our room would be available. Waited in line 15 minutes to do this, which is fine. Afterwards, we spent time in the pool til around 4pm. At which time, we checked our cellphone to find out our room was ready. Went back to front desk and the person checking me in, kept asking me if someone from my party had checked in earlier - which was a definite no because we stayed at the pool together the entire time. He went to the back to get our room keys... and couldn't find them. So he came back out and had to make new room keys. This whole process took about 30 minutes - which should have taken only a few minutes since I checked in earlier that day. Went to the room, which is definitely less than desirable (old carpets in bathroom, mold, actually it smelled like someone urinated in the room) - this place could definitely use some refurbishing. Anyways our room was located at the furtherest point from the lobby but was right next to the self-parking garage and way far away from valet parking. Because of this we decided to self park rather than use valet. However, everytime that we tried to self-park there were no parking spaces left. Finally, irritated we phoned the front desk... they said we could park in handicapped since there was no parking available. Our last complaint is that because we were leaving on an early flight the next morning - I visited the front desk to check-out early the night before. I was assured that we would be able to still get back into the room... wouldn't you know that when we returned (late at night with my 6 year old son) we couldn't get back into the room. So I called front desk and they told me that everything should be working correctly however they patched me through to someone else who then told me our keys were deactivated. So security had to come up and let us back in the room. Also, when I told the front desk of our dissatisfaction - it was only a grumble of - I'm sorry to hear that. The grounds of this hotel are very beautiful. The pools were lots of fun for my son. However, with all the problems I do not believe that it would be worth it to stay here again. We usually stay down the street at the Fairmont Kea Lani.. you can tell its a classy hotel compared to this dive. Would definitely not recommend staying here to anyone.

Reviews.Title: “Too big, too impersonal. Poor service. As fake as a Disney hotel.”
Reviews.Author: dddane
Reviews.Content: Disappointment is an understatment. We made our reservation about 10 months prior to checking in to the Grand Wailea. When we made our reservation, we specifically requested a king room. Upon arrival we were told they didn't have any king rooms left and only had a room with 2 queens. After the person went into the back room to talk to room control (I picture a geeky man with 10 monitors in front of him watching what customers in the lobby were doing), she came back. We were told that we could check back the next day, or they could "sheet 2 queen beds as one" and we wouldn't know the difference. The second option didn't sound so bad so we agreed. When we arrived in our room we found two queen beds pushed up against each other, not sheeted as one. You couldn't even pull the sheets or the comforter out of the bed because they were pushed up against each other. The headboards are attached to the wall, so they were not even behind the bed. It looked retarded and wasn't functional. (I posted a picture). Because the night stand normally is in the middle of the beds, of course there was only one night stand, which was about a 10 foot journey away from where I was to sleep. I'm paying $400 a night to put my glass on the floor and not be able to pull the comforter out from being tucked in? And, oh, did I mention it was the handicap room, so there were bars everywhere and all of the furniture was severely banged up. (For the record, we were paying about $400/night due to our group discount, but the cheapest rate I could find on our room type was about $800/night). The wallpaper was peeling off the walls and the room stunk. The tile shower was nasty, it had a fold up seat and the tile itself was groddy. My bathroom at home is by far nicer than this room. I have a hard time paying $400/night+ to stay at a place that's not as nice as what I have at home. There's nothing luxurious about that. The kicker here is my mom checked just before me the same day and she had requested 2 queens and ended up with 1 king in the same room type as I (which was an upgrade from the room type she had booked). So clearly the GW is very bad at planning and didn't even bother to read the customer requests. For the prices they charge, this is ridiculous. The next morning we went to ask if they had any rooms open up. She went into the control room and came back and told us no there was nothing they could do. No apology, just a "no." This was not a satisfactory answer so we pressed on. Eventually she came out of the control room and said they'd have a room available after the people checked out today. She told us to go to our rooms, bring our luggage to the lobby by noon, and they'd call us on our cell phone when the room was ready. (No offer of help from the bell captain). So we went to our room, and basically checked out by noon. We left our luggage with the bell captain and went off on our day. At about 4pm we went to the desk to ask why they hadn't called. They said they didn't have any rooms still. This was completely unsatisfactory, so we of course demanded something be done. Somewhere there was a king room in this monster of a hotel. After 10 minutes in the control room she came out and said they had a room and the baggage would be sent up. We were *shocked* to see that our luggage was still sitting at the bell captain desk in the middle of the lobby--for a good 6 hours. Much of the time there's nobody at the desk and anyone could've just walked up and stole the $5000 of electronics and other goodies I had in my bags (we were there for a wedding). All along, no apologies from the staff whatsoever. We went to our new room, waited about 30 minutes for our luggage before having to call to ask where it was. 10 minutes later half of our luggage arrived. They didn't know about the other half so they went back to check. That came another 15 minutes after. The bell captain--who was the only friendly person we talked to the entire time in our 10 day stay--told us he had been there since GW opened and since Hilton took over management it's gone downhill. They've laid off over 400 workers and raised the prices without making any improvements whatsoever. He explained our room was painted instead of wallpapered because that's there temporary fix for the mildew that grows all under the wallpaper. The room stunk like a wet basement, we had to keep the doors open the entire time otherwise it got much worse (and of course, every time the cleaning crew came they closed it, so every time we returned our room was nasty smelling). The room we were given was a JR. suite, which meant it had a nicer bathroom-the size of the room itself was the same. One of the chairs was instead replaced with a sofa (though as far as I can tell it was not a sofa that was purchased in the last 10 years), and the minibar was a little bigger. The service here is not what you'd expect from anything higher than a 3 star hotel. The employees reminded me a lot of airline employees. Many had been there a long time and reveled about what the Grand Wailea once was, and were probably jaded by what it is today. Pretty much everyone we encountered was just there squeaking by but not overly friendly, if at all friendly. When you stay at a Ritz or pretty much any hotel charging these types of rates, they greet you by your name at least once in awhile. Not once did anyone even attempt to mutter anything resembling my name. I'm not snobby or anything, but a hotel like this is made or broken by small, cute details like this that make you feel important. The desk staff were completely unfriendly. The setting in Maui is hard to ruin, really. A dumpy condo on a beach will still look beautiful. But it all felt really Disneyseque. The area of Wailea would basically be a desert if they hadn't altered the environment. Everything here is fake--trees, plants, waterfalls are all fake, nothing like this would naturally grow there or exist at this part of the island. It didn't feel remotely natural, this kind of rubbed me the wrong way... I could go to Disneyworld and see fake waterfalls, it's a much cheaper flight. I feel sorry for those who go to Grand Wailea and don't venture out beyond the area to see anything natural in its natural setting. Also, the palm trees were so high they blocked much of the ocean view you would have if they weren't so high. Even though it's next to the ocean, don't expect to hear the ocean... all you hear are the fake waterfalls. The place is too big. They show two parking lots on their map--what they don't tell you is one is valet only. The other one is at the far end of the hotel. Our room at the far opposite end of the hotel was a good 20 or 25 minute walk to our car; and the lot itself was constantly full. When parking, there were always people trolling the parking lot waiting for people to leave so they could have a spot. (Our friends who went at a different time of the year told us how they had the same problem and ended up parking at the lowest level in the employee parking area). The pools sound nice, but they're overran with bratty 10 year olds during the day whose parents are off sipping $13 margaritas. The pool closes at 11pm and the water slide and other water features are only open from 10am-5pm. The 2 or 3 waterslides and water elevator easily took about 15 minutes waiting in line to get in, and weren't really anything exciting. The water elevator was fun once or twice but really it was a lot of waiting around for nothing. The swim up bar wasn't open until noon and closed at 5. The food at the restaurants was severely overpriced. ($11 for a bagel and cream cheese). We ate breakfast there once, my eggs benedict I ordered had a plastic wrapper in the middle that I only discovered after chewing it in my mouth. They wouldn't comp it, only bring a new one. The $30 breakfast buffet didn't have anything too special on it. I personally thought ordering a breakfast entree ($25ish) was a better deal since it was actually something that was cooked to order. The golf course restaurant across the street (Sea Watch) was 1/2 the price, nicer view, quieter, and friendlier waitresses. We ate dinner at one of their other restaurants, both having different local fish specials. One of our fish entrees came out way way overdone. (Their onion rings are indeed amazing though). Our room wasn't thorougly cleaned the entire time we were there. Sure they made the bed and what not, but there were ring marks from glasses on our desk the entire time we were there. In fact there were a few ring marks when we arrived at our room the first day that weren't even ours. I had bought some bath salts at lush prior to arriving and had anticipating a nice soak in the tub or two, but after seeing it I didn't trust it was clean enough to actually do this... BTW, what luxury hotel these days doesn't give you slippers? Or bath salts? Or for that matter a refrigerator? Also, the maid seemed spacey in that one day she took our robes but didn't replace them, and another day our bath mat disappeared. We didn't have a room service menu--or any hotel information book in our room, so we called to ask for one. They didn't bring one, so we wrote a note to the cleaning woman the next day asking if we could have one. We were left with a photocopy of the room service menu, but no hotel info booklet. They nickel and dime you to death. $2.50/day for cleaning--just enough to not care, just enough to be annoyed that they bother to do it at all. $25 for a mini-fridge. The craziest charge I recall is a $10 *per person* to carry bags to your room (they don't tell you this until checkout). etc etc. When we pulled up to the lobby to unload our bags, a valet came and immediatly tried to take our keys and give us a valet tag. We told them we were just unloading bags. He took the keys anyway, saying that we couldn't drive the car to the side of the driveway ourself to let it sit for 5 minutes, he had to. After checking in, we returned to get our car and self parked it. At check out, there was a $25 or so valet charge on our bill from this incident. The in room high speed Internet isn't truly high speed. It's 128kbps, which is a lot slower than the cheapest DSL you can buy. It's not fast enough to support a business traveler who needs a VPN connection. You can upgrade to a true 512 kbps high speed at a cost of $15 a day. Also, they didn't provide an ethernet cable. The little black box has one built in but it was only 1', so you couldn't even move your laptop around on the desk let alone anywhere other than the desk. The access is provided by Lodgenet. Lodgenet charges the Grand Wailea for every "black box" they have connected, so what does Grand Wailea do? They unplug the black box from all of their rooms so they aren't registered on the system. The problem is nowhere do they tell you this, it's not designed to be unplugged so it's not in any instructions they have. I called the front desk to tell them my Internet wasn't working--without saying anything they forwarded my call to a 1-800 number and I had to chat on the phone for about 20 minutes before we realized what they did. I had to crawl on the floor to trace a cable that ran behind the TV in order to plug it back in. I called the front desk to complain of this, they acted like it was an accident. The problem is I was in 4 other rooms and they too ALL had the black Lodgenet box unplugged. One of our friends who was staying there at the time was mentioning her Internet wasn't working and just gave up. I imagine this is what the GW hopes for. I can't even believe what cheapskates the people running this hotel are! They do have wireless Internet but it's only designed to work in certain areas near the middle of the grounds in the outside area. Our first room we were able to pick up the signal if we moved to a certain area on the balcony though. On the second room we weren't able to even see the network in our list. How can a hotel charging $800/night for rooms not have wireless Internet? All in all, I've had better experiences at hotels that were 1/4 the price. Fake scenery. check. Jaded staff. check. Mildewy smell. check. Over-priceyness. check. Waldorf-Astoria? They only wish they were as nice as a real Waldorf-Astoria.

Reviews.Title: “Tropical resort caters to families and adults”
Reviews.Author: seanh007
Reviews.Content: Very charming resort with both beauty inside and out. Nice open air public spaces and spectacular pool. Some of the best gardens of any resort in the US. Excellent service from all levels of staff who keep the place clean and hopping. Rooms are spacious and clean but not over the top in decor but not basic either. But the balcony is the best part of the room if you must stay inside. Two pools: one for kids and one for adults so you can relax without teeny boppers splashing. Beach is tranquil. Fine dining. Be sure to reserve room with ocean view that overlooks the garden areas and the pools.

Reviews.Title: “Grand Wailea Fairy Tale”
Reviews.Author: waileabride
Reviews.Content: I got married at the Grand Wailea in May 2004. I want to write this review to encourage others who may want to get married on Maui because my wedding day at the Grand Wailea was so wonderful, stress free, and beautiful. I'd been to the Grand Wailea several times in my teens and thought that the wedding chapel was so gorgeous. I knew someday I'd want to get married there. I'd never stayed at the hotel until my wedding night. I did have several wedding planners and agree that something must be going on there because of the high turnover rate. Luckily, the 3rd wedding planner was the nicest and she was the one who oversaw my big day. I like to plan things myself, but it was nice to plan things myself, then have someone else worry about how it would all happen. The wedding, pictures, and especially that wedding DVD could not have been topped. The wedding planner we had was named Noelani. I was hoping our room would be ready for me to get ready in early in the day before our sunset wedding. Noelani called me the morning of the wedding to say that she was working on an upgrade for us. We'd booked a partial ocean view w/king bed. It was going to be about $700 and we were staying for 2 nights. When it was time to get ready to go to the hotel, Noelani called again to say that there was a room overlooking the chapel for me to get ready in, but that our room would not be ready until after the wedding and we could move our things then. I told her it was OK, I'd rather just have a room and not have to move. She told me that she had an upgraded room available and that I would probably like it, so I agreed and arranged for my sister and best friend to help out with moving things over. After our wedding and pictures, my sister came and said that everything was moved to our "upgraded" room. I asked if it was pretty nice. She said, "Yeah, if you like full panoramic view, several rooms, and two bathrooms." I said, "Really?" Not quite understanding what it might be. I thought maybe we'd have a full ocean view or something. Noelani upgraded us to the $6,000 per night Royal Hawaiian Suite. Only one room, a $10,000 room , was more grand. Our Royal Suite was so amazing, we brought everyone up to see it. I'll never forget what the Grand Wailea did for us. I didn't ask for an upgrade, they just did it. I also know that this may not happen to many other brides and it probably can't be expected. I was married on a Monday night. Maybe that had something to do with it. All I know is that I've never heard of anyone else receiving such royal treatment at a hotel on their wedding night. I saw the Four Seasons next door and it can't compare to the Grand Wailea Seaside Chapel as a place for a wedding. We just got back from the Hilton Waikoloa on the Big Island. I saw an outdoor wedding there and thought that maybe the Hilton could rival the Grand Wailea if you want an outdoor wedding. But if you want the most beautiful wedding chapel overlooking the ocean at a very grand hotel with beautiful wedding picture spots, then the Grand Wailea is the place to be.

Reviews.Title: “Incredible Time”
Reviews.Author: PZ13
Reviews.Content: First and foremost, I am not a picky traveler. My wife and I are in our late 20's. We stayed at the Grand Wailea from Sep.1-8. In the last three years we have been to St. Lucia (honeymoon), Atlantis-Bahamas and this year the Grand Wailea in Maui. I think that both the Atlantis and Grand Wailea blew away St. Lucia. We had a great honeymoon there at the time but after you travel to the other two hotels, you are in a different world. Yes, the Grand Wailea is expensive.... that is if you let it be. Yes, there is a $25 service charge per night that the hotel adds to your bill. We did arrive at 1:30 to find out our room was not ready. Were we annoyed after a long flight? Maybe slightly but c'mon this is a vacation, put all your annoyances and problems away, you are in Paradise! We took advantage of the time and familiarized our self with the resort, we walked around and check out the grounds. They called us in an hour and told us our room was ready, no bigggie. We had the Ocean View Room, which was great. We were in the Lagoon wing, where it was kind of tropical. The view was just fine. We had a partial view of the ocean but mostly it was the palm trees. They put us on the 3rd floor, which is the top level in that wing. We had a great view of one of the pools and it was very convenient having the pools right there. I think the biggest difference between the Atlantis and Grand Wailea was the convenience and that you have a balcony to enjoy the splendid view. The sunsets were unbelievable from our balcony! We only at the Resort three times in the 8 days we spent there. That was the one time we forked out $50 on lunch and drinks at the pool. The other two times we had room service. Yes, the pizza might have cost $20 but it was huge and neither of us could finish it. The second time we had a Turkey Club and a Grilled Chicken salad, which were good portions. That came out to be $35 with the service and delivery fee. Never would we step foot in the other restaurants, way too expensive for the food that you get. On the way from the airport we did stop by Safeway and bought some snacks, breakfast bars and most importantly a 24 pack of water. At the Grand Wailea water is not hard to come by but at the Atlantis it's like $5 a bottle, absolute rip off! We also loaded up on alcoholic beverages and made our own mixers in our room. I would advise you to have them bring you a fridge to your room for a one time $25 fee, it is worth it, believe me! I Instead of dining at the resort we found some good places in Kihei, a town that is right next to Wailea. Make sure you rent a car in Maui, it only cost us $150 for a week through Alamo and we got a Mustang convertible. That was the smartest thing we ever did. There is a great breakfast place in Kihei right off Pilani Hwy. I read about this place on one of the reviews here. They are so nice there, it's a hole in the wall but the food is soooo good and they prices are so reasonable. For two, with a 20-25% tip, we walked out of breakfast for in between $18-23. We had breakfast there twice and we also went there for lunch one time. Lunch came out to be in between $25-$30 with tip, which is not too bad. The macadaimia banana nut pancackes were to die for. I would suggest getting just two, I made the mistake of getting 3 and I only finished 1/2 my meal and I can eat. They also have great potatoes for bkfast. For lunch we got a turkey club wrap and the mahi mahi wrap, both were fabulous, I would have to give the edge to the mahi mahi wrap. There was this other breakfast place that we ate at in Kihei, after our surfing lessons, that was awesome. It is right off S. Kiehi road. I believe the name was Kihei cafe, it's another hole in the wall, they serve breakfast all day and open at 5am. It is right across the street from a park where we took our surfing lessons. Make sure you get a seat on the outdoor patio, it can get crowded there come 8am. For dinner, besides the two times we had room service or the Luau that we attended, we ate at Moose McGillycuddy's. We enjoyed our experience the first time that we went back again. The fish tacos are heaven there and their happy hour from 3-6 rocks. They have $2 Mai Tai's, $2 beers, it's awesome. They have a incredible view of the ocean, both times we ate there, we were sat next to a window and watched the beautiful Maui sunsets. Next door is Fred's, it's a Mexican bar & pub from what I heard the best margaritta's and great food. It seemed like Fred's was the place to be, but we enjoyed the laid back Moose McGillycuddy's. Plus the service there was great. Both times we got out of there for under $55. This included drinks, appetizer, two meals, and desert. Not bad for Maui if you ask me! Maybe it was easier for us to go out and explore the island since we did not have kids and drive around to find these places. I know for some people it is easier to just stay at the resort and dine. There was this one restaurant at the shops at Wailea that the food was absolutley atrocius, it was some burger joint that I could not remember the name of. I thought 8 days on Maui was not enough. You need atleast 10-14 to be able to do a good amount of stuff. We went on a 5 hour snorkeling adventure which was awesome. We also took surfing lessons, a must! There was the helicopter tour of West Maui and Molokai, the Sunrise on top of Haleakala Volcano and the 28 mile bike down following- awesome adventure. I recommend doing this the first or second day you are there, as you are still on your mainland time.... they pick you up from your hotel at 2:30am. It makes it for a long day as you get dropped back off at noon. The one activity we looked forward to doing was the ziplines, I had booked those two weeks ahead of time, as it can be hard to book with the popularity of them. That morning after a one hour drive to Kannapali from Wailea, they call us when we are 5 minutes from their store and tell us all tours have been canceled due to a technical malfunction. We were really disappointed as we really had been looking forward ot this. So, we had to make the best of it and book another adventure. All in all, we had a fabulous time in Maui. I mean c'mon, it's Hawaii for gosh sakes! It's a time where you get a chance to get away from the everyday hussle and bussle and just relax. We would for sure come back to Maui. Next time we might stay up North by Lahaina and Kannapali just to try something new but I wouldn't mind staying at the Grand Wailea again.

Reviews.Title: “Nice resort”
Reviews.Author: vashtiseven
Reviews.Content: Overall, this was a pleasant stay. The grounds are beautiful and the beach was just a few steps away from the rooms. The view from our room in the chapel wing was amazing. I found most of the staff to be pleasant and accommodating. With all of that said, I don't think I would pay $600.00 a night for the room I stayed in. (I went with my husband on a business trip and his employer foot the bill) The rooms are nice, but nothing extravagent. The bathrooms are in need of some serious TLC. The tiles are white and the grout is orange or brown. The shower door was water stained and the room smelled like mildew. Also, I agree with my fellow reviewers regarding the nickel and diming going on at the Grand Wailea. The Grand Wailea takes full advantage of charging for anything extra. (Example: we were charged $18.00 just to print our boarding passes.) Also, we ate at the Huma Huma restaurant and were very disappointed. (High prices and not very good food.)
